question_text: A 55-year-old woman had an autonomic neuropathy that disrupted the sympathetic nerve supply to the pupillary dilator muscle of her right eye. While having her eyes examined, the ophthalmologist placed a sympathomimetic drug in both her eyes. The right eye became much more dilated than the left eye. This suggests that:
options: The sympathetic nerve to the right eye had regenerated
The parasympathetic nerve supply to the right eye remained intact and compensated for the loss of the sympathetic nerve
The left eye also had nerve damage and so was not responding as expected
explanation: Denervation supersensitivity develops in the muscle after the nerve supplying it is cut. Since the nerve to her right dilator pupillae is damaged, the right eye becomes excessively sensitive to the sympathomimetic drug. So, the right eye becomes much more dilated than the left. Denervation Supersensitivity: When the motor nerve to skeletal muscle is degenerated, the muscle gradually becomes extremely sensitive to acetylcholine. This is called denervation hypersensitivity or supersensitivity. Normally nicotinic receptors are located only in the vicinity of the motor endplate where the axon of the motor nerve terminates. When the motor nerve is severed, there is a marked proliferation of nicotinic receptors over a wide region of the neuromuscular junction. Denervation supersensitivity also occurs at autonomic junctions. Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not atrophy when denervated, but it becomes hyperresponsive to the chemical mediator that normally activates it. This hyperresponsiveness can be demonstrated by using pharmacologic tools rather than actual nerve section. Prolonged use of a drug such as reserpine can be used to deplete transmitter stores and prevent the target organ from being exposed to norepinephrine for an extended period. Once the drug usage is stopped, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle will be supersensitive to subsequent release of the neurotransmitter. Option b) Parasympathetic nerves supply the spinchter pupillae muscle. So, if stimulated they would constrict the eye not dilate it. Also, the drug added was a sympathomimetic agent. So, parasympathetic nerves are not stimulated in the first place Option d) If the left eye was damaged, it would also have denervation supersensitivity. Again, both eyes would dilate equally, but more than that of normal.

How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse?

question_text: Which of the following neurotransmitter is not a biogenic amine?
explanation: Glycine is not a biogenic amine. It is an amino acid. Biogenic amines are made from amino acid precursors. They have a nitrogen containing amine (NH2) group. explanation: The most important neurotransmitter of reward pathway is dopamine. explanation: Corticostrial pathway is not a dopaminergic pathway. The corticostrial pathway is the primary input pathway for the basal ganglia which uses glutamate as the neurotransmitter. question_text: A patient with involuntary jerking and writhing movements is diagnosed with Huntington's disease. Loss of which of the following is responsible for hyperkinetic symptoms in this condition?
explanation: The hyperkinetic feature of Huntington's disease is due to the loss of intrastriatal GABAergic and cholinergic neurons. question_text: An infant develops features of botulism following honey intake. This toxin blocks neuromuscular transmission by which of the following mechanisms?

Prevents the binding of Ach at the postsynatic membrane
Prevents the action of Ach at the postsynaptic membrane
explanation: Botulinum toxin prevents the release of Ach at the presynaptic membrane. Botulinum toxins A, B, and E are toxic to humans. question_text: A farmer presents with difficulty swallowing and jaw tightening. He gives a history of getting his finger jammed in the rustic gate a few days ago. He gives no history of previous tetanus immunization. After evaluation, he was diagnosed with tetanus. The release of which of the following neurotransmitters is affected by the toxin responsible for this condition?
explanation: Tetanus toxin affects the release of GABA. Tetanus toxin escapes normal lysosomal degradation and crosses the synapse to the GABA-ergic presynaptic inhibitory interneuron terminals. The toxin blocks the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters (glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid) across the synaptic cleft. This blockage of the inhibitory neurotransmitters causes spastic paralysis.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The neurotransmitter released by Renshaw cell interneuron is .
explanation: The neurotransmitter released by Renshaw cell interneuron is glycine. Renshaw cell is an inhibitory interneuron which is activated by collaterals from spinal motor neurons. Renshaw cell terminates on the cell body of the same and other spinal motor neurons. It reduces or stops the discharge of the motor neuron by releasing glycine.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following neurotransmitters is increased during REM sleep?
explanation: Acetylcholine increases during REM sleep. In REM sleep, there is increase in acetylcholine and decrease in norepinephrine and serotonin. The reverse of this pattern leads to wakefulness. Neurotransmitters in REM sl eep Levels of neurotransmitte r Acetylcholine Increased Serotonin Decreased Norepinephrine Decreased
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is the wrong match?
options: Sympathetic post ganglionic fibres - release noradrenaline
Sweat glands - innervated by sympathetic adrenergic fibres
explanation: Sweat glands are innervated by sympathetic cholinergic fibres (not adrenergic fibres). Pre-ganglionic fibres of the sympathetic nervous system, pre-ganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic nervous system and post-ganglionic parasympathetic fibres release acetylcholine. Post-ganglionic sympathetic fibres release noradrenaline in most of the sites, except in certain places such as sweat glands, piloerector muscles and blood vessels in some skeletal muscles where acetylcholine is released.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which part of the basal ganglia is the neurotransmitter glutamate secreted from?
explanation: Projections from subthalamic nucleus to globus pallidus are glutaminergic. Neurotransmitters secreted by various regions of basal ganglia: Substantia nigra pars compacta = dopamine Substantia nigra pars reticulata = GABA Subthalmic nuclei = glutamate Corpus striatum to globus pallidus = GABA Intrastriate neurons = acetylcholine Globus pallidus = GABA Diagrammatic representation of the principal connections of the basal ganglia. Acetylcholine is the transmitter produced by interneurons in the striatum. (SNr : substantia nigra pars reticulata; SNc: substantia nigra pars compacta; STN: Subthalamic nucleus ; GPe: globus pallidus externa ; GPi: Globus pallidus interna).
subject: Physiology

question_text: All of the following are excitatory neurotransmitters except:
explanation: Serotonin is an inhibitory neurotransmitter. Acetylcholine, glutamate and norepinephrine are excitatory neurotransmitters.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is not true about serotonin receptor?
explanation: 5-HT2C receptor agonists increase satiety (state of being fed beyond capacity). Important serotonin receptors: 5-HT2A receptors mediate platelet aggregation and smooth muscle contraction. 5-HT3 receptors are present in the GIT and the area postrema and are related to vomiting. 5-HT4 receptors are present in the GIT and brain. They facilitate secretion and peristalsis in GIT. 5-HT6 and 5-HT7 are distributed throughout the limbic system. Note: All are G protein coupled receptors except 5-HT3 which is a ligand gated ion channel receptor.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Serotonin is present in highest concentration in
explanation: Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine; 5-HT) is present in highest concentration in platelets and in the gastrointestinal tract, where it is found in the enterochromaffin cells and the myenteric plexus. It is also found within the brain stem in the midline Raphe nuclei. Note: The precursor of serotonin is tryptophan.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
Which statement regarding the NMDA receptor is incorrect?
Glutamate is its endogenous agonist
options: Glycine is essential for this receptor's response to its endogenous agonist
It is a chloride ion channe
It is present in hippocampal neurons
explanation: NMDA receptor permits passage of Ca2+ and other cations (Na+), not of chloride. Glutamate is the agonist for NMDA receptor. Glycine binding to the NMDA receptor is essential for the receptor to respond to glutamate. NMDA receptors are present on hippocampal neurons. Note: GABA and glycine receptors act by increasing Cl- conductance. Sensory Receptors
subject: Physiology

question_text: Spatial distribution from which a stimulus produces a response is called
explanation: Spatial distribution from which a stimulus produces a response is called receptive field. Sensory Unit: A single afferent neuron with all its receptor endings. Motor unit: Each single motor neuron and the muscle fibers it innervates. Dermatome: Each spinal nerve innervates a “segmental field” of the skin.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Fast vibration sense is mediated by .
explanation: Fast vibration sense is mediated by Pacinian corpuscles. Pacinian corpuscle is the most sensitive mechanoreceptor in the somatosensory system. It is responsive to high-frequency (30–500 Hz) vibratory stimuli and pressure. They are rapidly adapting receptors. Option A: Merkel's disc sense touch and sustained pressure. They are slow adapting receptors. Present in epidermis. Option B: Meissner's corpuscle sense tap and flutter. They are present in dermal papillae. They are rapidly adapting receptors. Option D: Ruffini endings sense skin stretch and fluttering vibration. The following image shows Merkel's disc and Meissner's corpuscle being more superficial (reponsive to touch) than Ruffini endings and Pacinian corpuscle (which are deeper in the dermis and responsive to pressure).
subject: Physiology

question_text: The phasic receptor is
explanation: Meissner's corpuscles are phasic (rapidly adapting) receptors. Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, and muscle spindle are tonic (slowly adapting) receptors.
subject: Physiology

question_text: You are doing a CNS examination of a patient with a spinal injury. At which of the following sites would the distance of two-point discrimination be greatest?
explanation: The distance of two-point discrimination is greatest at the back of the scapula. The relative tactile acuity of a given region can be determined by the two-point discrimination test. Here, calipers are used to determine the minimum distance between the two points which can be perceived as two points. Greater the density of receptors  Smaller the receptive field  More precise the localization. For e.g., Stimulus points on the back, for instance, must be separated by at least 65 mm before they can be distinguished as separate, whereas on the fingertips two stimuli are recognized if they are separated by as little as 2 mm. The lips have the greatest acuity (two-point discrimination threshold ~ 1 mm). Clinical significance: Blind individuals benefit from the tactile acuity of fingertips to facilitate the ability to read Braille. The dots forming Braille symbols are separated by 2.5 mm. Two-point discrimination is used to test the integrity of the dorsal column (medial lemniscus) system.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true about the nature of the sensory receptor given below:
explanation: The sensory receptor shown in the above image is Pacinian corpuscle. The Pacinian corpuscle is a rapidly adapting receptor and is an encapsulated receptor. When a stimulus of the same strength is continuously given to a sensory receptor, the frequency of the action potentials generated by the receptor gradually decreases. This phenomenon is known as receptor adaptation. Depending on whether the receptor stops responding to a stimulus rapidly or slowly, they are classified as rapidly adapting (phasic) or slow adapting receptors (tonic).
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following classification of receptors is the same?
explanation: Mechanoreceptors and exteroceptors have the same classification of receptors. Exteroceptors are concerned with the external environment or receptors which receives external stimuli. Mechanoreceptors are cutaneous receptors for touch and pressure. Thus mechanoreceptors can be considered to be exteroceptors. Nociceptors are pain receptors which detect physical and chemical damage occuring in the tissue. Interoceptors are concerned with the internal environment. Chemoreceptors are receptors stimulated by a change in the chemical composition of the environment in which they are located. These include receptors for taste and smell as well as visceral receptors such as those sensitive to changes in the plasma level of O2, pH, and osmolality. Teleceptors (distance receivers) are concerned with events at a distance, example - photoreceptors. Proprioceptors provide information about the position of the body in space at any given instant.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding sensory receptor properties?
options: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the intensity of the stimulus
A touch receptor will generate a constant rate of discharge of its axon for as long as the eceptor is stimulated
Meissner’s and Pacinian corpuscles adapt slowly, the others adapt rapidly
The frequency of a train of action potentials in an afferent fibre reflects the intensity of the stimulus given to its recepto
explanation: The frequency of a train of action potentials in an afferent fibre reflects the intensity of the stimulus given to its receptor. Intensity of stimulus applied to a sensory receptor can be determined by the following: Variation in frequency of action potentials generated Variations in the number of receptors activated Option A : Weber-Fechner Law states that magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus. Option B: A touch receptor will not generate a constant rate of discharge, even if the receptor is continuously stimulated. This is called desensitization or adaptation. If the opposite were true (if option B was correct), when we have our clothes on, we would have constant firing of neurons unnecessarily, in response to touch stimulus. Option C: Slowadapting(Tonic receptor s) Rapidlyadapting(Phasic rece ptors) Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end o rgans, Joint capsule Muscle s pindle, Golgi tendon organs Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner' s corpuscles, Hair end organs
subject: Physiology

question_text: A fibers do not transmit .
explanation: A fibers do not transmit slow pain. They transmit fast pain. Activation of A fibers, which release glutamate, is responsible for first pain (also called fast pain or epicritic pain), which is a rapid response and mediates the ability to localize the site and intensity of the noxious stimulus. Neuropathic pain can also be burning, dull and poorly localized (protopathic pain, transmitted by C nociceptor fibers (which release substance P). Dual Pain Pathway Pain can be carried by either A fiber (fast pain/ epicritic pain) or by C fiber (slow pain/protopathic pain) Feature Afiber C fibe Stimuli MechanicalThermal Polymodal Myelination and trac t Myelinatedand carried viaNe ospinothalamic tract Unmyelinatedand carried via paleospinothalamic tract Conduction velocity 12–30 m/s 0.5–2 m/s Impulse conduction Fast componentof pain Slow componentof pain Feature Afiber C fibe Neurotransmitter Glutamate Substance P
subject: Physiology

question_text: The most potent algogenic substance is .
explanation: Bradykinin is the most potent algogenic substance. An algogenic substance is a chemical released at the site of injury which mediates pain. These include bradykinin, serotonin, histamine, potassium ions, acids, acetylcholine, and proteolytic enzymes. Prostaglandins and substance P enhance the sensitivity of pain endings but do not directly excite them. Note: This is a controversial question According to Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition, Page 622- "One chemical that seems to be more painful than others is bradykinin. Researchers have suggested that bradykinin might be the agent most responsible for causing pain after tissue damage." Hence, bradykinin is the better answer (not serotonin)
subject: Physiology

question_text: Vanilloid receptors are activated by all except .
explanation: Vanilloid receptors are not activated by vibration. Vanilloid receptors or TRPV1 (transient receptor potential vanilloid1) receptors are a part of family of nonselective cation channels called transient receptor potential (TRP) channels. These channels respond to intense heat, acids, and chemicals such as capsaicin.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Heat-pain fibers are stimulated at temperatures around .
explanation: Heat-pain fibers begin to be stimulated at around 45 °C. Thermal Receptors and their Excitation Cold receptor Warm receptor Peak:24 °C Peak:45 °C. Cold nociceptor stimulated w hen temperature is around5 ° C. Heat nociceptor is stimulated at temperatures around45 ° C. Cold receptor fibers areA an d C Warm receptor fibers areun myelinated C fibers
subject: Physiology

question_text: Weber-Fechner law relates magnitude of sensation to .
explanation: Weber-Fechner Law states that the magnitude of sensation felt is proportionate to the log of the intensity of the stimulus. Other Laws in Physiology: Doctrine of specific nerve energies - When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ are stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized no matter how o where along the pathway the activity is initiated. Law of projection - No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor. This principle is called the law of projection.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient's right leg was amputated because it was unsalvageable after the motor vehicle accident. After 2 weeks of her surgery, she started feeling episodes of severe pain in the amputated area. This pain is most likely based on which of the following mechanisms?
explanation: This patient is having phantom limb pain. This pain is based on cortical plasticity. Cortical structures are capable of reorganization after the loss of a body part. The cortical representation of the neighboring parts spreads into the cortical area that was formerly occupied by the representation of the amputated part. This is called cortical plasticity leads to the phenomenon of phantom limb pain
subject: Physiology

question_text: Perception of normal sensory stimuli as painful is
explanation: Perception of normal sensory stimuli as painful is allodynia. Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated response to a noxious stimulus. An example of primary hyperalgesia is the extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin, which results from sensitization of the skin pain endings by local tissue products released due to burns — histamine, prostaglandins, and others. Causalgia is a type of neuropathic pain.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true about anandamide?
options: There are anandamide-containing neurons in the periaqueductal gray
explanation: There are anandamide-containing neurons in the periaqueductal gray and other areas concerned with pain. There are 2 types of endogenous cannabinoids: 2-arachidonyl glycerol and Anandamide. They bind to CB1 and CB2 receptors. They have an anti-nociceptive effect. Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray inhibit transmission in nociceptive pathways. This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla (Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releases endogenous opiates.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true about visceral pain?
options: It is mediated by B fibers
explanation: Visceral pain is poorly localized, unpleasant and associated with nausea and autonomic symptoms. It often originates from thoracic and abdominal cavities, transmitted through small type C pain fibers. It often radiates (or is referred) to other somatic structures perhaps due to convergence of somatic and visceral nociceptive afferent fibers on the same second-order neurons in the spinal dorsal horn that project to the thalamus and then to the primary somatosensory cortex. When pain is referred, it is usually to a structure that developed from the same embryonic segment or dermatome as the structure in which the pain originates. This principle is called the dermatomal rule. Example: the heart and the arm have the same segmental origin. subject: Physiology

question_text: Pain insensitive structure is .
explanation: Alveoli are pain insensitive structures. Alveoli of lungs and parenchyma of liver are almost completely insensitive to the pain of any type. However, the liver capsule is extremely sensitive to both direct trauma and stretch. The bile ducts, arterial walls, bronchi and the parietal pleura are very sensitive to pain.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient with chronic pain is undergoing transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation for pain relief. What is the basis of this procedure?
explanation: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) of pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain. This method uses electrodes to activate A and A fibers near the injury to relieve pain. Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. The relief may result from inhibition of pain pathways (Inhibition of C fibers and A-delta fibers) in the dorsal horn gate, by stimulation of large-diameter touch-pressure afferents(A-beta fibers). This is called the gate-control hypothesis. Interesting clinical application: Touching or shaking an injured area decreases the pain due to the injury. Stimulation with an electric vibrator at the site of pain also gives some relief. The same mechanism is probably responsible for the efficacy of counterirritants. Stimulation of the skin over an area of visceral inflammation produces some relief of the pain due to the visceral disease. The old-fashioned mustard plaster works on this principle.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Primary cutaneous hyperalgesia
options: Develops in the normal skin region around the area of flare
Is an abnormal condition in the skin in which painful stimuli become less severe
Is due to changes in threshold of pain receptors
Is associated with throbbing type of pain
explanation: Hyperalgesia is an exaggerated response to a noxious stimulus. Hyperalgesia and allodynia signify increased sensitivity of nociceptive afferent fibers. Causes of hyperalgesia The excessive sensitivity of the pain receptors, which is called primary hyperalgesia Facilitation of sensory transmission, which is called secondary hyperalgesia. An example of primary hyperalgesia is the extreme sensitivity of sunburned skin, which results from sensitization of the skin pain endings, by local tissue products from the burn — histamine, prostaglandins, and others. Secondary hyperalgesia frequently results from lesions in the spinal cord or the thalamus.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The transient receptor potential (TRP) channel that is most active at normal skin temperature is .
explanation: At normal skin temperatures, TRPV3 is the most active receptor.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to you in the ER. In order to rule out hypothermia, how do you best measure his temperature?
Oral
explanation: In the given clinical scenario rectal temperature would be the preferred site to measure the core body temperature. During low or high temperatures like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures are highly misleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperatures Infrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum which is representative of core body temperature. However, more often the thermometer is not inserted adequately or for safety reasons, they are manufactured in such a way that they do not reach deep into the ear canal, or the ear canal contains cerumen which can disturb the measurement. Hence the infrared thermometer more commonly delivers the temperature of ear canal cerumen and hence not a reliable method of measuring the core body temperature. Somatosensory Pathways
subject: Physiology

question_text: The principle that “ In spinal cords, dorsal roots are sensory and ventral roots are motor” is known as
explanation: The principle that in the spinal cord the dorsal roots are sensory and the ventral roots are motor is known as the Bell–Magendie law. Laws in Sensory Physiology Muller's doctrine of specific nerve energies: When the nerve pathways from a particular sense organ are stimulated, the sensation evoked is that for which the receptor is specialized, no matter how or where along the pathway the activity is initiated. Law of projection: No matter where a particular sensory pathway is stimulated along its course to the cortex, the conscious sensation produced is referred to the location of the receptor. Weber-Fechner Law: Magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the log of the intensity of the stimulus. Labelled line theory: All the sensations from the different parts of the body travel along specified paths. For example, in the posterior column, fibers from the lower parts of the body are placed medially.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient admitted to the ward does not feel a sensation of the heat on touching a hot object. Considering the signal reaches the thalamus, which of the following is not transmitting the signal to an intact postcentral gyrus?
explanation: In this scenario, the tertiary neuron does not transmit the signal to the postcentral gyrus. In the thalamus, secondary sensory neurons synapse onto tertiary sensory neurons, which in turn project to the somatosensory region of the cerebral cortex. The question tests your knowledge of this pathway. It is said that the signal reaches the thalamus and the postcentral gyrus is intact. Still, the person cannot perceive the sensation, so the pathway is broken between the thalamus and the gyrus, which has to be at the tertiary neuron.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Decussation of ascending spinal pathways occurs mainly within the
explanation: Decussation of ascending spinal pathways occurs mainly within the spinal cord and medulla oblongata. Most of the ascending pathways and tracts do decussate or cross; however, some remain uncrossed. Dorsal column pathway crosses in the medulla oblongata. The anterior and lateral spinothalamic tract crosses obliquely in the spinal segments.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Conscious proprioception is carried by .
explanation: Conscious proprioception is carried by dorsal column. Unconscious proprioception is carried by spinocerebellar tract. Option B and C: Anterolateral system carries pain, temperature, crude touch.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is not a property of fibers in the dorsal column pathway?
explanation: The dorsal column–medial lemniscal system is composed of large, myelinated nerve fibers and thus transmit signals to the brain, at high velocities of 30 to 110 m/sec. Option B: Dorsal column carries fine touch and anterolateral column carries crude touch
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient comes to you for his annual health checkup. He lost his vision due to an accident a few years ago. He now experiences the world through touch. Which of the following Brodmann’s areas processes this tactile stimulation?
explanation: Processing of tactile stimulation occurs in Brodmann’s area in 3, 1, 2. The human cerebral cortex is divided into about 50 distinct areas called Brodmann’s areas based on histological structural differences. Areas 3, 1, 2 which constitute primary somatosensory area I, and areas 5 and 7, which constitute the somatosensory association area process sensory information like tactile stimulation.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Cortical representation of body in the cerebrum is
explanation: Cortical representation of body in the cerebrum is vertical. Parts of the body are represented in order along the postcentral gyrus, with the legs on top and head at the bottom of the gyrus. A cortical homunculus is a distorted representation of the human body, based on a neurological map of the areas and proportions of the human brain dedicated to processing motor functions, or sensory functions, for different parts of the body. The size of the cortical receiving area for impulses from a particular part of the body is proportionate to the use of the part. Sensory Homunculus is a topographical representation of distribution of sensory input to the somatosensory cortex from different parts of the body. Motor homunculus is a topographical representation of distribution of motor output from primary motor cortex to different parts of the body. Sensory homunculus is depicted below:
subject: Physiology

question_text: Somatosensory area has the largest representation for
explanation: Somatosensory area has the largest representation for lips. The relative sizes of the cortical receiving areas of the sensory homunculus are proportionate to the use of the part. The sizes of these areas are directly proportional to the number of specialized sensory receptors in each respective peripheral area of the body. Some body parts are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex—the lips the greatest of all, followed by the face and thumb, whereas the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient sustains an injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the right hemisphere. Loss of sensation is likely to be seen at which of the following sites in this patient?
explanation: In this case, injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the right hemisphere would result in loss of sensation in the left facial area. Each hemisphere receives somatic sensory information from the opposite side of the body in the postcentral gyrus (somatosensory area). The lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus receives somatic sensory information from the facial and neck region while the medial portion of the postcentral gyrus received somatic sensory information from the trunk and appendages.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Lesion of somatosensory area I affects
explanation: Lesion of the somatosensory area I affects the localization of sensations. Bilateral lesion of the somatosensory area I leads to the following impairment of sensory judgment: Inability to localize different sensations in different parts of the body Inability to judge° of pressure against the body Inability to judge the weight of the objects Inability to judge shapes of forms of objects - astereognosis Inability to judge the texture of the materials Pain and temperature are not affected both in quality and intensity in the lesion of the somatosensory area I. However, they are poorly localised. Pain and temperature localization depends greatly on the topographical map of the body in somatosensory area I to localize the source.`
subject: Physiology

question_text: A man was rushed to the casualty after getting stabbed in the back with a knife. On MRI, a complete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?
options: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Only pain lost on the same side
explanation: This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side. Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome. The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion. The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion. Damage to the corticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following findings are seen in a patient with Brown-Sequard syndrome?
options: Upper Motor Neuron type of paralysis below the lesion on the opposite side
Impaired fine touch below the lesion on the opposite side
Loss of crude touch below the lesion on the same side
Loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side
explanation: A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have a loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side. Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the Spinal cord. It can be caused by fracture-dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor. Clinical features: Pyramidal tract: Pyramidal weakness (ipsilateral upper motor neuron type of paralysis) below the level of the lesion on the same side as the lesion (pyramidal tract crosses in the medulla). Dorsal columns: Impaired fine touch, 2 point discrimination, proprioception, vibration below the level of lesion on the same side of lesion (dorsal column fibres cross in the medulla). Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure sensation below the leve of the lesion on the contralateral side of the lesion (spinothalamic tract crosses midline after entering the cord).
subject: Physiology

question_text: Itch is carried by
explanation: Itch-specific fibers have been demonstrated in the anterolateral spinothalamic tract. They are carried by unmyelinated nerve fiber C. Itching can be produced by repeated local mechanical stimulation of skin, variety of chemical agents including histamine and kinins released in the skin in response to tissue damage Simple scratching relieves itching because it activates large fast conducting afferents (A) that gate the transmission in the dorsal horn in a manner analogous to inhibition of pain by stimulation of similar afferents (Gate control theory).
subject: Physiology

question_text: Following are the endogenous opioids except
explanation: Endogenous opioids, a group of neuropeptides that includes beta-endorphin, dynorphins, and enkephalins. Opioids cause both presynaptic and post synaptic inhibition reducing excitatory post-synaptic potential (EPSP). Opioids are released from the descending analgesic pathway and bind with opiate receptors on the afferent pain-fiber terminal. This binding suppresses the release of substance P, blocking further transmission of the pain signal.
subject: Physiology

question_text: You are examining a patient for a follow-up of severe pain in his right leg. He tells you that he feels much better now that he is taking acupuncture therapy too. Which of the following is responsible for pain relief in acupuncture?
explanation: Pain relief in acupuncture is by the release of endorphin. The acupuncture endorphin hypothesis is the primary mechanism of acupuncture analgesia. According to this hypothesis, Acupuncture is thought to activate afferent neurons leading to spinal cord and midbrain centers that release endogenous opioids implicated in pain relief.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Fast pain is carried by
explanation: Fast pain is carried by neospinothalamic tract. Pain signals take two pathways to the brain: Neospinothalmic tract for fast pain/epicritic pain (A fibres) Paleospinothalamic tract for slow pain/Protopathic pain (C fibres)
subject: Physiology

question_text: Soldiers wounded in the heat of battle often feel no pain until the battle is over which is an example of stress-induced analgesia. This is due to
explanation: Stress induced analgesia is due to cannabinoids. The stress-induced analgesia, i.e., reduced pain sensitivity during stressful events might be due to: Release of endogenous cannabinoids such as 2-arachidonoylglycerol (2-AG) and anandamide Release of Norepinephrine from brainstem catecholaminergic neurons in the amygdala.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following does not carry proprioceptive impulses?
explanation: Tectocerebellar tract does not carry proprioceptive impluses. Tectocerebellar tract carry visual and auditory impulses. Spinocerebellar, olivo cerebellar, cuneo cerebellar tracts carry Proprioceptive impulses. Vestibulocerebellar tract carry vestibular impulses.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Pain and temperature in the thalamus are controlled by which of the following nuclei?
explanation: Pain and temperature in thalamus are controlled by the ventral posterior lateral nucleus. Pain and temperature is carried by anterolateral spinothalamic tract. Fibres from anterolateral spinothalamic tract and dorsal column synapse in the ventral posteriorlateral (VPL) nucleus of thalamus. Option B: The pathway from taste receptors includes synapses in the nucleus of the tractus solitarius in the brainstem and ventral posterior medial nucleus in the thalamus. Option C: Anterior nucleus functions as a relay station for the hippocampal impulses. It receives afferents from mammillothalamic tract. It sends efferents to cingulate gyrus. Option D: Intralaminar nucleus participates in arousal reaction, it recieves afferents from reticular formation of brain stem.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Ventrolateral cordotomy for relief of pain in the right lower limb is being performed on a patient. Which of the following is cut in this procedure?
explanation: In ventrolateral cordotomy, selected pain-conducting tracts in the spinal cord, i.e. fibers in the lateral spinothalamic pathway, are cut leading to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. In the more recent percutaneous approach, destruction of the lateral spinothalamic at the level of C1-C2 results in a contralateral disruption of painful sensations beyond C4. Note: The fibers carrying pain sensation ascend in the lateral spinothalamic tract while the fibers carrying crude touch and pressure sensations ascend in the anterior spinothalamic tract.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Pick the correct statement:
options: Spinal lemniscus carries fibres of dorsal spinothalamic tract
Trigeminal lemniscus carries pain and temperature sensations from the ipsilateral orofacia region
Lateral lemniscus carries fibres from cochlear nuclei
Medial lemniscus carries fibres from of vestibular nuclei
explanation: Lateral lemniscus carries fibres from cochlear nuclei Medial lemniscus carries fibres from of dorsal column nuclei Spinal lemniscus carries fibres of anterolateral spinothalamic tract Trigeminal lemniscus carries pain and temperature sensations from the contralateral orofacial region
subject: Physiology

question_text: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?
options: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side
explanation: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side. Fibers of medial lemniscus ascend ipsilaterally in the dorsal columns of the spinal cord to the medulla, where they synapse in the gracilus and cuneate nuclei. The second-order neurons from these nuclei cross the midline and ascend in the medial lemniscus to end in the contralateral ventral posterior lateral (VPL) nucleus and related specific sensory relay nuclei of the thalamus.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
Ablation of somatosensory area 1 leads to
Total loss of pain sensation
options: Loss of tactile but not 2 point discrimination
Loss of tactile and 2 point discrimination
explanation: Ablation of somatosensory area 1 leads to Loss of tactile and 2 point discrimination. Widespread bilateral excision of the somatosensory area I causes loss of the following types of sensory judgment: The person is unable to localize discretely the different sensations in the different parts of the body. However, he or she can localize these sensations crudely, such as to a particular hand. The brain stem, thalamus, or parts of the cerebral cortex can perform some degree of localization. The person is unable to judge critical° of pressure/weight/texture. Special Senses

question_text: Light entering the eye first passes through retinal layer.
explanation: Light passes first through the retinal ganglion layer, the most anterior/inner layer of the retina. Light then passes through other layers of the retina until it reaches the photoreceptors in the posterior/outer region of the retina. Retina is organized into 10 layers or zones where distinctive components are clustered together to form continuous strata. Light passes in the direction: Vitreous humor(anterior) choroid(most posterior) encountering the cell layers in that direction (ganglion cell layerphotoreceptors) Visual processing/Phototransduction occurs in the opposite direction (Photoreceptors ganglion cell layer)
subject: Physiology

question_text: Initiation of visual impulse is associated with
options: Condensation of opsin with Vitamin A
Photoisomerisation and hydrolysis of visual purple
explanation: Initiation of visual impulse is associated with photoisomerisation and hydrolysis of visual purple Rhodopsin or visual purple, the photosensitive pigment, is composed of opsin (a protein belonging to the superfamily of G protein–coupled receptors) and retinal (an aldehyde of vitamin A). When light strikes the photoreceptors, retinal is chemically transformed in a process called photoisomerization, which begins the transduction process.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which form of vitamin A combines with opsin to make rhodopsin?
explanation: 11-cis –retinaldehyde combines with opsin to make rhodopsin. All-trans retinol is one form of Vitamin A which is converted to 11-cis retinol under the influence of Isomerase. Finally, 11-cis retinol is converted into 11-cis retinal which combines with Scotopsin to form rhodopsin.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding distribution of rods and cones in retina?
options: Macula lutea is the blind spot
low density of photoreceptors are present in macula
Peripheral retina has greater cones to rods ratio
explanation: Central fovea (foveola) contains only cones (rod-free area) and is a region of highest resolution. question_text: The rod receptor potential differs from other surface receptors in that it shows .
explanation: The rod receptor potential differs from other surface receptors in that it shows hyperpolarization. In most sensory receptors: Arrival of stimulus  Ion channels are opened up allowing current to flow => depolarisation of the receptor. In photoreceptors: When the light strikes the outer segment, a cascade of reactions (refer figure) are initiated, that close some of the Na+ channels in the outer segment and results in hyperpolarization.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which is the first-order neuron in the optic pathway?
explanation: Photoreceptors - rods and cones are the first-order neurons in the visual pathway.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Purely depolarizing cells in optic pathway are
explanation: The responses of the rods, cones, and horizontal cells are hyperpolarizing, and the responses of the bipolar cells are either hyperpolarizing or depolarizing, whereas amacrine cells produce purely depolarizing potential.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Amacrine cells secrete
explanation: Amacrine cells release acetylcholine. Amacrine cells are one of the neuronal cell types of the retina. They transmit signals in two directions, either directly from bipolar cells to ganglion cells or horizontally within the inner plexiform layer from axons of the bipolar cells to dendrites of the ganglion cells or to other amacrine cells. Amacrine cells release GABA, glycine, dopamine, acetylcholine & indolamine. Other neuronal cell types of the retina are: The photoreceptors: rods & cones Horizontal cells Bipolar cells Ganglion cells Of these cell types, only neurotransmitters secreted by photoreceptors & amacrine cells have been discovered. Rods and cones release glutamate at their synapses with the bipolar cells.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The only neurons in retina showing action potential are
explanation: All neural elements in the retina exhibit local graded potentials except ganglion cells which shows action potential.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The fibers from contralateral nasal retina project to the following layers of lateral geniculate nucleus
explanation: On each side, layers 1, 4, and 6 of the lateral geniculate nucleus receive input from the contralateral eye, whereas layers 2, 3, and 5 receive input from the ipsilateral eye. (Refer figure).
subject: Physiology

question_text: Parvocellular pathway carries signal for detection of
explanation: From the Lateral Geniculate Nucleus (LGN), a magnocellular pathway (from layers 1 and 2) and a parvocellular pathway (from the rest of the layers) project to the visual cortex. Parvocellular pathway Magnocellular pathway Receive input entirely from t ype X retinal ganglion cells, a nd transmit color. question_text: The axons from lateral geniculate nucleus terminate in layer of primary visual cortex.
explanation: The axons from the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) mostly end in layer 4. The primary visual receiving area (primary visual cortex) is located principally on the sides of the calcarine fissure and has 6 layers similar to the neocortex. Layer 4 recieves most of the input from the LGN, which is divided further into 4A, 4B, 4C , and 4C. The magnocellular pathways from layers 1 and 2 of the LGN end in layer 4C while the parvocellular pathways from layers 3-6 of the LGN end in layer 4C.
subject: Physiology

question_text: An ophthalmologist explains to a patient that he is a protanope. These patients have difficulty in identifying which of the following color?
explanation: Protanopes are dichromats with difficulty in identifying red color. Anomalous Trichromatic Vision Deficiency of red is Protanomaly. Deficiency of green is Deuteranomaly. Deficiency of blue is Tritanomaly. Dichromatic Vision (Individuals with only two cone systems) Blindness to red color Protanopia (Protanope). Blindness to green color Deuteranopia (Deuteranope). Blindness to blue color Tritanopia (Tritanope). Monochromatic Vision Have only one cone system. Color blindness is X-linked recessive. subject: Physiology

question_text: Auditory information is relayed through thalamic nucleus.
explanation: The medial geniculate nucleus is the thalamic nucleus that conveys auditory information from the brainstem to the primary auditory cortex. Lateral geniculate nucleus is the thalamic nucleus that conveys visual information.
subject: Physiology

question_text: In the auditory pathway, which is the first structure that can determine the direction of the perceived sound?
explanation: The superior olivary nuclei receive information from both ears and begin the process of detecting the direction from which a sound comes. The eighth nerves reach their respective cohlear nuclei in the medulla from where the nerves travel to both the ipsilateral and contralteral superior olivary nuclei in the pons and hence giving it the ability to detect the direction of the sound. The lateral part of superior olivary nucleus does so by comparing the difference in intensities of sound reaching the two ears, whereas the medial part of the superior olivary nucleus detects the time lag between the signals entering the two ears.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following events prompts the auditory system to interpret a sound as loud?
options: Decreased number of inner hair cells become stimulated
Decreased number of outer hair cells become stimulated
Hair cells excite nerve endings at a diminished rate
Amplitude of vibration of the basilar membrane increases
explanation: There are at least three ways that the auditory system determines loudness: As the sound becomes louder- the amplitude of vibration of the basilar membrane increases so that hair cells excite the nerve endings at more rapid rates. As the amplitude increases- more and more hair cells on the fringes of the resonating portion of the basilar membrane become stimulated. As the amplitude of vibration reaches high intensity, the outer hair cells become recruited at a significant rate.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Umami taste is evoked by
explanation: Umami taste is triggered particularly by the monosodium glutamate (MSG) used so extensively in Asian cooking. Taste Receptors Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, salt, sour, bitter and umami. The taste receptors for these five basic tastes are of two major types: Ligand-gated channels (ionotropic receptors): for salt and sour taste G-Protein Coupled Receptors (metabotropic receptors): for sweet, bitter and umami Salt and sour taste are mediated through epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) Na+ movement through ENaC salt taste H+ movement through ENaC  sour taste Sweet, bitter, and umami are sensed via GPCRs T1R2 and T1R3 families sweet taste T2R family  bitter taste Metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4)  Umami
subject: Physiology

question_text: Mitral cells are seen in
explanation: Mitral cells are seen in Olfactory bulb. Axons of Olfactory nerves (First cranial nerve) synapse with the mitral cells and tufted cells in the olfactory bulb to form anatomically discrete units called olfactory glomeruli. The olfactory bulb also contains periglomerular cells that are inhibitory interneurons and granule cells that make reciprocal synapses with mitral and tufted cells. These mitral and tufted cells (second-order neurons) terminate in Olfactory cortex.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following sensory systems has the smallest range of intensity discrimination?
explanation: The olfactory system has the smallest range of intensity discrimination. Smell is concerned more with detecting the presence or absence of odors , than with the quantitative detection of their intensities. Concentrations that are only 10 to 50 times above threshold values will evoke maximum intensity of smell, which is in contrast to most other sensory system of the body.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Number of cones in the retina (millions) is
explanation: There are approximately 6 million cones and 120 million rods in each human eye. Features of Photoreceptors Each rod and cone are divided into outer segment, inner segment, nuclear region and a synaptic zone. Saccules and discs in the outer segment contain photosensitive pigments. If a person spends a considerable length of time in brightly lighted surroundings and then moves to a dimly lighted environment, the retinas slowly become “accustomed to the dark.” This decline in visual threshold is known as dark adaptation. It is nearly maximal in about 20 min, much longer than the time taken for light adaptation which is 5 min. When one passes suddenly from a dim to a brightly lighted environment, the light seems intensely and even uncomfortably bright until the eyes adapt to the increased illumination and the visual threshold rises. This adaptation occurs over a period of about 5 min and is called light adaptation.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?
Optic nerve
explanation: The site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract. Wernicke hemianopic pupil is the light reflex, where, illumination of the blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction while stimulating the normal side of the retina shows a pupillary reaction. It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilis and tumours of the optic thalamus. Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma. Motor Physiology - 1
subject: Physiology

question_text: Each muscle spindle consists of intrafusal fibers.
explanation: Each muscle spindle is 3 to 10 millimeters long. It is built around 3 to 12 tiny intrafusal muscl fibers that are attached to the glycocalyx of the surrounding large extrafusal skeletal muscle fibers. Each intrafusal muscle fiber is a tiny skeletal muscle fiber. However, the central region of each of these fibers has few or no actin and myosin filaments. Therefore, this central portion does not contract when the ends do. Instead, it functions as a sensory receptor. The end portions that do contract are excited by small gamma motor nerve fibers.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Motor supply to muscle spindle is
explanation: Motor supply to muscle spindle is  Muscle spindles have a motor nerve supply of their own.These nerves belong to Erlanger and Gasser’s A■ group. They are just 3–6  in diameter (hence called small motor nerve system/■ efferents of Leksell) and go exclusively to muscle spindles. Note: Motor innervation of muscle spindle is by gamma efferents Motor innervation of extrafusal fibers is by alpha motor neurons Nuclear bag muscle fibers: 1–3 per muscle spindle. Nuclear chain muscle fibers: 3–9 per muscle spindle.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Identify the type of nerve fibre in the diagram below.
explanation: In the given figure, the fiber in yellow innervates the ends of the muscle spindle. Therefore, it is a gamma motor neuron. Many much smaller gamma motor neurons are located in the spinal cord anterior horns (shown as the yellow efferent fiber). These gamma motor neurons average 5 micrometers in diameter, which go to small, special skeletal muscle fibers called intrafusal fibers or the muscle spindle. These fibers constitute the ends of the muscle spindle, which help control basic muscle “tone.” Option (b): The alpha motor neurons (shown as the blue efferent fibre) are on an average 14 micrometers in diameter. These fibers branch many times after they enter the muscle and innervate the large skeletal muscle fibers at the motor endplate. Stimulation of a single alpha nerve fiber excites anywhere from three to several hundred skeletal muscle fibers, which are collectively called the motor unit. Option (c): A-beta fibers are fibers for touch and pressure. Option (d): A-delta fibers are fibers for pain and temperature.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is false with respect to muscle spindles?
options: The intrafusal and extrafusal fibers are positioned paralled to each other
The primary endings of intrafusal fibers are most sensitive to a dynamic respons
Type II nerve fibers do not innervate static nuclear bag fibers
Two types of  motor neurons supply the muscle spindl
explanation: Type II nerve fibers do innervate the static nuclear bag fibers. They do not innervate dynamic nuclear bag fibers. A muscle spindle has: Intrafusal fibers - these are tiny skeletal muscles which have few or no actin and myosin filaments in the central portion. This portion acts as a sensory receptor. Extrafusal fibers These fibers are positioned parallel to each other (Option A). There are two types of intrafusal fibers: Nuclear bag fibers - subdivided as dynamic and static nuclear bag fibers Nuclear chain fibers Sensory nerve supply: There are two types of sensory endings: Primary endings - (annulospiral ending) from Type Ia nerve fibers. This innervates both th nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers. They are most sensitive to the velocity of the change in muscle length. This is called a dynamic response. (Option B) Secondary endings - from Type II nerve fibers. This innervates static nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers. They do not innervate dynamic nuclear bag fibers. (Option C) Both primary and secondary endings show a static response. Motor nerve supply: The muscle spindles are supplied by  motor neurons. There are two types of  motor neurons- dynamic that supply dynamic nuclear bag fibers and static that supply static nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers. (Option D)

explanation: The nuclear bag fibers sense the dynamic length of the muscle. Nuclear bag fibers are intrafusal fibers, which are a part of the muscle spindle. question_text: The afferents for deep tendon reflexes innervate
explanation: The afferents for deep tendon reflexes innervate both - nuclear bag and chain fibers. The afferents for the DTRs are the type Ia and type II nerve fibers. There are three types of intrafusal muscle fibers: dynamic nuclear bag, static nuclear bag, and nuclear chain fibers. A single Ia afferent fiber innervates all three types of fibers to form a primary sensory ending. A group II sensory fiber innervates nuclear chain and static bag fibers to form a secondary sensory ending. Deep tendon reflexes are an example of stretch reflex or myotatic reflex.

explanation: Stretch reflex occurs when the muscle is stretched passively. Stretch (myotatic) reflex is monosynaptic. (As illustrated in the figure given below, steps 15).
