question_text: Withdrawal reflexes are not
options: Prolonged if the stimulus is strong
An example of a flexor reflex
Accompanied by the same response on both sides of the body
explanation: Withdrawal reflexes are not accompanied by the same response on both sides of the body. On the ipsilateral side of the pain stimulus, flexors are stimulated (they contract) and extensors are inhibited (they relax), and the arm is jerked away from the stove. On the contralateral side, flexors are inhibited and extensors are stimulated (crossed extension reflex) to maintain balance. It results in flexion on the ipsilateral side and extension on the contralateral side. Somatosensory and pain afferent fibers elicit withdrawal of the stimulated body part from the noxious stimulus. Pain (e.g., touching a hot stove) stimulates the flexor reflex afferents of groups II, III, and IV. The afferent fibers synapse polysynaptically (via interneurons) onto motoneurons in the spinal cord. As a result of persistent neural activity in the polysynaptic circuits, an afterdischarge occurs. The afterdischarge prevents the muscle from relaxing for some time.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The maintenance of normal posture depends on
explanation: The maintenance of normal posture depends on the Integrity of reflex arc. The muscles that maintain upright posture—that is, support the body’s weight against gravity—are controlled by the brain and by reflex mechanisms. Three levels of the nervous system control movement: The spinal cord, which integrates spinal reflexes and contains central pattern generators. The brain stem and cerebellum, which control postural reflexes and hand and eye movements. The cerebral cortex and basal ganglia, which are responsible for voluntary movements.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Receptor for inverse stretch reflex
explanation: Golgi tendon organ is the receptor for inverse stretch reflex (refer figure). The Golgi tendon organs, unlike the spindles, are in series with the muscle fibers; therefore, they are stimulated by both passive stretch and active contraction of the muscle. The degree of stimulation by contraction of muscles is much greater than that caused by the stretching of muscles. Muscle contraction  Ib fibers from the Golgi tendon organ excite an inhibitory interneuron that releases inhibitory mediator glycine  hyperpolarization (inhibition) of  motor neurons  muscle relaxation.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The number of muscle fibers per Golgi tendon organ is .
explanation: There are 3-20 muscle fibers per Golgi tendon organ. Golgi tendon organ consists of a netlike collection of knobby nerve endings among the fascicles of a tendon. There are 3–25 muscle fibers per Golgi tendon organ. The fibers from the Golgi tendon organs make up the Ib group of myelinated, rapidly conducting sensory nerve fibers. Golgi tendon organs help in regulating the velocity of the muscle contraction, muscle length, and muscle force. They are the receptor for inverse stretch reflex.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The inverse stretch reflex
options: Occurs when Ia spindle afferents are inhibited
Is a monosynaptic reflex initiated by activation of the Golgi tendon organ
Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs
Is a polysynaptic reflex with many interneurons inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs
explanation: Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite, or inverse, of the stretch reflex. When tension on the muscle—and therefore on the tendon—becomes extreme, the inhibitory effect from the golgi tendon organ can be so great that it leads instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction; it is probably a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.
subject: Physiology

question_text: All of the following are true about withdrawal reflex except
options: Diverging circuits to spread the reflex to the necessary muscles for withdrawal are present
Circuits to inhibit the antagonist muscles, called reciprocal inhibition circuits are present
Circuits to cause afterdischarge that lasts many fractions of a second after the stimulus is over are present
The pathways for eliciting the flexor withdrawal reflex pass directly to the anterior motor neurons making it a monosynaptic reflex
explanation: The pathways for eliciting the flexor withdrawal reflex do not pass directly to the anterior motor neurons; instead, they first pass into the spinal cord interneuron pool of neurons and only secondarily to the motor neurons. The shortest possible circuit is a three- or four-neuron pathway. The following basic types of circuits are present: Diverging circuits to spread the reflex to the necessary muscles for withdrawal; Circuits to inhibit the antagonist muscles, called reciprocal inhibition circuits; and Circuits to cause after-discharge are present. They prolong the reflex contraction of the muscles that last many fractions of a second after the stimulus is over. The flexor reflex is organized to withdraw a pained or otherwise irritated part of the body from a stimulus. Further, because of after-discharge, the reflex can hold the irritated part away from the stimulus for 0.1 to 3 seconds after the irritation is over. During this time, other reflexes and actions of the central nervous system can move the entire body away from the painful stimulus.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Muscle tone is maintained by
explanation: The resistance of a muscle to stretch is often referred to as its tone or tonus and muscle spindle helps to control basic muscle tone. The tonic (static) stretch reflex circuit includes both group Ia and group II afferent fibers from muscle spindles. Normally, there is ongoing activity in the Ia and II afferents that helps maintain a baseline firing of  motor neurons; therefore, the tonic stretch reflex contributes to muscle tone.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true during initiation of voluntary movements?
options:   motor neurons are activated followed by  motor neuron
  motor neurons are activated followed by  motor neuron
Both  and ■ motor neurons are activated together
explanation: The cell bodies of  and  motor neurons to a given muscle lie close together. Both types are activated by interneurons in their immediate vicinity and sometimes directly by neurons of the descending pathways. During many voluntary and involuntary movements, they are coactivated, i.e., they are excited at almost the same time. ( -■ coactivation) The purpose of  -■ coactivation: First, it keeps the length of the receptor portion of the muscle spindle from changing during th course of the whole muscle contraction. Hence, the muscle contraction is not opposed by th stretch reflex. Second, if the muscle spindle did not contract and relax along with the large muscle fibers, th receptor portion of the spindle would sometimes be flail and sometimes be overstretched. Coactivation thus ensures that information about muscle length will be continuously available to provide for adjustment during ongoing actions and to plan and program future movements.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Righting reflex is
explanation: Righting reflexes operate to maintain the normal standing position and keep an animal's head upright. These reflexes are a series of responses integrated for the most part in the nuclei of the midbrain.
subject: Physiology

question_text: In a patient with decerebrate rigidity, on applying pressure on the footpad, extension of that limb occurs. Which of the following statements is false regarding this phenomenon?
options: It is integrated at the Spinal Level
It helps to prevent falling on that sid
It is a righting reflex integrated at midbrain level
explanation: Pressure on the footpad of a decerebrate patient causes the limb to extend against the pressure applied to the foot. This reflex is called the positive supportive reaction and is a righting reflex integrated at the spinal level. Pressure on one side causes extension in that direction (e.g., on applying pressure on the right footpad, extension of the right lower limb occurs), an effect called the magnet reaction. It is seen in infants and following spinal transection. From an evolutionary perspective, this reflex helps to prevent falling on the side where the stimulus is given.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Pyramids are formed by
explanation: The corticospinal pathways are also called the pyramidal tracts or pyramidal system because of their triangular shape as they pass along the ventral surface of the medulla oblongata.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true about corticospinal tract?
explanation: The corticospinal tract contains crossed fibers (majority). Fibers of the corticospinal tract originate from the primary motor cortex (about 30%), the premotor and supplementary motor areas (30%), and the somatosensory areas posterior to the central sulcus (40%). Most fibers (80% fibers) decussate (cross) in the medullary pyramids and descend in the lateral white matter of the spinal cord to form the lateral corticospinal tract. They control the movements of the contralateral limbs. The remaining 20% make up the ventral corticospinal tract. These fibers remain uncrossed until reaching the spinal cord where axons terminate bilaterally on spinal interneurons antecedent to motor neurons. These fibers control the movements of the axial musculature.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding the origin of corticospinal tract?
options: Corticospinal tract fibers originate from Betz Cells
30% from premotor and supplementary motor areas
explanation: 30% of corticospinal tract originates about from the primary motor cortex, not 90%. 30 % from the premotor and supplementary motor areas. 40 % from the somatosensory areas posterior to the central sulcus. Betz cells Some large myelinated fibres in the corticospinal tract originate from giant pyramidal cells, also known as Betz cells. Found in the layer 5 of primary motor cortex. These large fibers represent only 3 percent of the total fibers of the corticospinal tract. (Th other 97 percent less than 4 micrometers in diameter that conduct background tonic signals to th motor areas of the cord.)
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is not an extrapyramidal tract?
explanation: Corticospinal tract is a pyramidal tract . Pyramidal tracts (corticospinal and corticobulbar) pass through the medullary pyramids. All others are extrapyramidal tracts and originate primarily in the the brain stem.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which pathway is not involved in maintainence of posture?
explanation: Rubrospinal tract is not involved in posture maintenance. Medial motor system Controls the axial muscles (muscles of the trunk) Axial muscles are concerned with postural adjustments and gross movements Lateral motor system Controls the distal muscles Distal muscles mediate fine, skilled movements
subject: Physiology

question_text: Gamma motor neurons are mainly influenced by
explanation: The pontine and medullary reticulospinal tracts are involved in maintainance of posture and in modulating muscle tone especially via an input to ■- motor neurons. Pontine reticulospinal neurons are primarily excitatory and medullary reticulospinal neurons ar primarily inhibitory. Stimulation of -motor neurons does not lead directly to detectable contraction of the muscles because the intrafusal fibers are not strong enough or plentiful enough to cause shortening. However, stimulation does cause the contractile ends of the intrafusal fibers to shorten and therefore stretches the nuclear bag portion of the spindles, deforming the endings, and initiating impulses in the Ia fibers . This in turn can lead to reflex contraction of the muscle. Thus, muscles can be made to contract via stimulation of the  -motor neurons that innervate th xtrafusal fibers or the -motor neurons that initiate contraction indirectly via the stretch reflex.
subject: Physiology

question_text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except
options: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the ■ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock
explanation: In decerebrate rigidity, there is rigidity in extensor muscles of all the four extremities (not all muscles of the body). Decerebration Complete transection of the brain stem between the superior and inferior colliculi permits th brain stem pathways to function independently of their input from higher brain structures. This is called a mid-collicular decerebration. This lesion interrupts all input from the cortex (corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts) and red nucleus (rubrospinal tract), primarily to distal muscles of the extremities. The excitatory and inhibitory reticulospinal pathways (primarily to postural extensor muscles) remain intact. The dominance of drive from ascending sensory pathways to the excitatory reticulospinal pathway leads to hyperactivity in extensor muscles in all four extremities which are called decerebrate rigidity. The excitatory input from the reticulospinal pathway activates -motor neurons which indirectly activate  -motor neurons (via Ia spindle afferent activity). This is called the gamma loop. Option 4. Spinal shock is different from decebrate rigidity as it is a transient state that can occur immediately after a spinal cord injury. It is characterized by a temporary loss or depression of spinal reflexes below the level of the injury.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true for decorticate rigidity?
options: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia
Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs
It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs
explanation: Removal of the cerebral cortex (decortication) produces decorticate rigidity. Characterized by flexion of the upper extremities at the elbow and extensor hyperactivity in th lower extremities. The flexion can be explained by active rubrospinal excitation of flexor muscles in the upper xtremities; the hyperextension of lower extremities is due to the same changes that occur after midcollicular decerebration.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following reflex is absent in a decorticate animal?
explanation: The Hopping and Placing reflex is absent in a decorticate animal as it is integrated in the cerebral cortex. Rest of the reflexes are integrated below the cortex.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Destruction of anterior cerebellum in a decerebrate animal leads to .
options: Increased rigidity via alpha motor neuron
explanation: Destruction of the anterior cerebellum in a decerebrate animal leads to an increased rigidity via alpha motor neuron. If the anterior lobe of the cerebellum is removed in a decerebrate animal, extensor muscle hyperactivity is exaggerated (decerebellate rigidity). This cut eliminates cortical inhibition of the cerebellar fastigial nucleus and secondarily increases excitation to vestibular nuclei. Subsequent dorsal root section does not reverse the rigidity, hence proving that the rigidity is due to activation of  -motor neurons independent of the gamma loop.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Upper Motor Neurons (UMN) include
explanation: Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. Corticospinal tract contain a population of large myelinated fibers with a mean diameter of 16 micrometers. These fibers originate from giant pyramidal cells, called Betz cells, that are found only in the primary motor cortex.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A 30-year-old man meets with an accident and develops spinal cord transection. Which of the following features will be seen as a result of pyramidal tract injury below the level of motor decussation?
explanation: Cutting the pyramidal tract below the decussation (UMN lesion) causes abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign). It initially causes muscles to become weak and flaccid but eventually leads to spasticity, hypertonia (increased resistance to passive movement), and hyperactive stretch reflexes. The image below shows the pyramidal tract (corticospinal pathway).
subject: Physiology

question_text: A 36-year-old male patient presented to the ER following a road traffic accident. Which of the following features would not be present if there is a corticospinal tract involvement?
explanation: Cog-wheel rigidity is not seen if there is a corticospinal tract involvement. Cogwheel rigidity is seen in extrapyramidal tract involvement when there is a tremor superimposed on hypertonia (e.g., Parkinsonism). In an upper motor neuron lesion, there is damage to the corticospinal or corticobulbar fibres. If the corticospinal fibres are damaged, it leads to diminished or loss of superficial reflexes, shows an extensor plantar response (Babinski's sign) with loss of fine skilled movement and spasticity.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
While exercising, a 42-year-old woman developed sudden onset of tingling in her right leg and an inability to control movement in that limb. A neurologic exam showed a hyperactive
knee jerk reflex and a positive Babinski sign. Which of the following is not true regarding her condition?
options: Reflexes can be modified by impulses from various parts of the CNS
Reflexes may involve simultaneous contraction of some muscles and relaxation of others
Reflexes are chronically suppressed after spinal cord transection
Reflexes often occur without conscious perception
explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of spinal cord transection, which is characterized by an exaggeration of reflexes and not suppression. Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons. Damage to these neurons, as in transection of the spinal cord, initially causes muscles to become weak and flaccid but eventually leads to spasticity, hypertonia (increased resistance to passive movement), hyperactive reflexes, and abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign).
subject: Physiology

question_text: A 50-year-old man with a history of medically controlled atrial fibrillation develops sudden onset weakness in the right side of his body. Which of the following Broadman's area is most likely affected?
explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of an acute stroke, most probably due to atrial fibrillation induced thromboembolism. Since the patient has developed motor weakness in the right side of his body, he most likely has an infarct affecting the primary motor cortex ( broadmann area 4). The primary motor cortex (or just the motor cortex) can be defined as the region of the cortex from which movements are elicited with the least amount of electrical stimulation. It is essentially congruent with Brodmann's cytoarchitectonic area 4. The primary motor cortex (M1) is in the precentral gyrus of the frontal lobe, extending into th central sulcus.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Skilled voluntary movement is initiated by
explanation: Commands for voluntary movements originate in cortical association areas. The corticospinal and corticobulbar system (originating in the motor cortex located in precentral gyrus) is the primary pathway for the initiation of skilled voluntary movement. The movements are planned in the cortex as well as in the basal ganglia and the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres. The basal ganglia and cerebellum funnel information to the premotor and motor cortex by way of the thalamus. Motor commands from the motor cortex are relayed in large part via the corticospinal tracts to the spinal cord. Movement sets up alterations in sensory input from the special senses and from muscles, tendons, joints, and the skin. This feedback information, which adjusts and smooths movement, is relayed directly to the motor cortex and to the spinocerebellum.
subject: Physiology

question_text: In the homunculus, which of the following has maximum representation?
explanation: In a homunculus, the more the representation of an area, the more precise the movements are. The relative sizes of the cortical receiving areas of the sensory homunculus are proportionate to the use of the part. The sizes of these areas are directly proportional to the number of specialized sensory receptors in each respective peripheral area of the body. Some body parts are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex—the lips the greatest of all, followed by the face and thumb, whereas the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas.
subject: Physiology

question_text: In the° of representation of the different muscle areas as mapped by Penfield and Rasmussen in the primary motor cortex, which of the following has the maximum representation?
explanation: As seen from the figure given below, Vocalization > Salivation > Mastication > Thumb The topographical organization is demonstrated graphically in the figure, which shows the° of representation of the different muscle areas as mapped by Penfield and Rasmussen. This mapping was done by electrically stimulating the different areas of the motor cortex in human beings who were undergoing neurosurgical operations. The face is represented bilaterally. The rest of the body has a unilateral representation.
subject: Physiology

question_text: While doing a neurosurgical procedure, the paracentral lobules of both hemispheres were damaged. It will lead to which of the following?
explanation: Damage to both paracentral lobules will cause paraplegia. The paracentral lobule is the medial continuation of the precentral and postcentral gyri. It controls motor and sensory innervations of the contralateral lower extremity. It is also responsible for the control of defecation and urination.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Setting posture before planned movement is associated with .
explanation: The premotor cortex may be concerned with a setting posture at the start of a planned movement and getting the individual prepared to move. It is most involved in control of proximal limb muscles needed to orient the body for movement. It is located anterior to the precentral gyrus, on the lateral and medial cortical surface; it also contains a somatotopic map almost identical to the topographic organization in primary motor cortex with the mouth and face areas located most laterally. As one moves upward, the hand, arm, trunk, and leg areas are encountered. (as seen in the figure below) This region receives input from sensory regions of the parietal cortex and projects to primary motor cortex (M1), the spinal cord, and the brainstem reticular formation. A special class of neurons called mirror neurons becomes active when a person performs a specific motor task or when he or she observes the same task performed by others. These neurons transform sensory representations of acts that are heard or seen into motor representations of these acts.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
A quadriplegic man with a high cervical lesion develops sudden onset of flushing, sweating, pounding headache and hypertension. He has a distended bladder due to a blocked urinary catheter. On immediate drainage of the urinary bladder and repositioning him from supine to reclining, his symptoms resolve. Which of the following is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?
SBP may rise over 200 mm Hg
options: Major portion of the body’s skeletal muscle go into extensor spasm
Large areas of the body break out into profuse sweating
explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of spinal mass reflex which is seen in patients with a high spinal lesion. A major portion of the body’s skeletal muscles goes into strong flexor spasm, and not extensor spasm, in a spinal mass reflex. Mass Reflex: In a spinal animal or human being, sometimes the spinal cord suddenly becomes excessively active, causing massive discharge in large portions of the cord. The usual stimulus that causes this excess activity is a strong pain stimulus to the skin or excessive filling of a viscus, such as over-distention of the bladder or the gut. The mass reflex involves large portions or even all of the cord. The effects are as follows: A major portion of the body’s skeletal muscles goes into strong flexor spasms; The colon and bladder are likely to evacuate; The arterial pressure often rises to maximal values, sometimes to a systolic pressure well over 200 mm Hg; and Large areas of the body break out into profuse sweating. The mechanism is similar to the mechanism of epileptic seizures, which involve reverberating circuits that occur in the brain instead of in the cord. Motor Physiology - 2
subject: Physiology

question_text: When dynamic -motor neurons are activated at the same time as  -motor neurons to muscle,
options: Prompt inhibition of discharge in spindle Ia afferents takes place.
The number of impulses in spindle Ia afferents is smaller than when  discharge alone is ncreased.
The number of impulses in spindle Ia afferents is greater than when  discharge alone is ncreased.
explanation: When dynamic -motor neurons are activated at the same time as  -motor neurons to muscle, the number of impulses in spindle Ia afferents is greater than when  discharge alone is increased. When  – coactivation occurs, intrafusal and extrafusal fibers shorten together, and spindle afferent activity can occur throughout the period of muscle contraction. Stimulation of -motor neurons causes increase discharge in spindle Ia afferent, leading to reflex contraction of the muscle. When a muscle contracts it leads to shortening of the muscle spindles and so impulses in the Ia afferents decreases. Thus, muscles can be made to contract via stimulation of the  -motor neurons that innervate the extrafusal fibers or the -motor neurons that initiate contraction indirectly via the stretch reflex. If the whole muscle is stretched during stimulation of the -motor neurons, the rate of discharge n the Ia fibers is further increased. Increased -motor neuron activity thus increases spindle sensitivity during stretch. This is the basis of the Jendrassik manouver.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The myogram below shows a slow onset and a longer after-discharge. Which type of reflex does it represent?
explanation: The figure shows the typical myogram recorded from a muscle involved in a crossed extensor reflex. This myogram demonstrates the relatively long latency before the reflex begins and the long after-discharge at the end of the stimulus. When a painful stimulus is applied to the body, the flexor withdrawal and the crossed extensor reflexes are stimulated. About 0.2 to 0.5 seconds after the flexor reflex in one limb, the opposite limb begins to extend. This reflex is called the crossed extensor reflex. After the painful stimulus is removed, the crossed extensor reflex has an even longer period of after-discharge than does the flexor reflex. This prolonged after-discharge results from reverberating circuits among the inter-neuronal cells. Compare the myograms of a flexor reflex with a crossed extensor reflex. In the flexor reflex, the contraction occurs immediately after applying the stimulus and the after-discharge is smaller.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The bulboreticular facilitatory area of the brain stem excites the gamma efferent system. This bulboreticular area receives impulses from which of the following areas?
explanation: Impulses are transmitted into the bulboreticular area from Cerebellum, Basal ganglia, and Cerebral cortex. The gamma efferent system is excited by signals from the bulboreticular facilitatory region of the brain stem. When the bulboreticular facilitatory region transmits excitatory signals through the gamma nerve fibers to the intrafusal muscle fibers of the muscle spindles, it shortens the ends of the spindles and stretches the central receptor regions, thus increasing their signal output. If the spindles on both sides of each joint are activated at the same time, then reflex excitation of the skeletal muscles on both sides of the joint increases, producing tight, tense muscles opposing each other at the joint. The net effect is that the position of the joint becomes strongly stabilized. Any time a person must perform a muscle function that requires a high degree of delicate and exact positioning, the bulboreticular facilitatory region of the brain stem stabilizes the positions of the proximal joints.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following describes components of the central pathway responsible for control of posture?
options: The pontine reticulospinal pathway terminates on neurons in the dorsomedial area of the spinal ventral horn that innervate flexor muscles.
The tectospinal pathway terminates on neurons in the dorsolateral area of the spinal ventral horn that innervate limb muscles.
The medullary reticulospinal pathway terminates on neurons in the ventromedial area of the spinal ventral horn that innervate axial and proximal muscles.
explanation: The medullary reticulospinal pathway terminates on neurons in the ventromedial area of the spinal ventral horn, that innervate axial and proximal muscles. The medullary reticular nuclei transmit inhibitory signals to the antigravity anterior motor neurons by way of the medullary reticulospinal tract, located in the lateral column of the cord. Option A: The pontine reticular nuclei transmit excitatory signals through the pontine reticulospinal tract in the anterior column of the cord. The fibers of this pathway terminate on the medial anterior motor neurons that excite the axial muscles of the body, that is the muscles of the vertebral column and the extensor muscles of the limbs. Option B: The tectospinal tract originates in the superior colliculus of the midbrain. It projects to the contralateral cervical spinal cord to control head and eye movements.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is not a medial pathway involved in maintenance of posture?
explanation: The rubrospinal tract is a part of the lateral brainstem pathway. The medial brainstem pathways : pontine and medullary reticulospinal, vestibulospinal, and tectospinal tracts. These pathways descend in the ipsilateral ventral columns of the spinal cord and terminate predominantly on interneurons in the ventromedial part of the ventral horn to control axial and proximal muscles. The lateral brainstem pathways : The corticospinal tract and the rubrospinal tract. They cross the midline and project to interneurons in the dorsolateral part of the spinal ventral horn to also influence motor neurons that control distal limb muscles. The rubrospinal tract excites flexor motor neurons and inhibits extensor motor neurons. This pathway may play a role in the posture typical of decorticate rigidity.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Increased neural activity before a skilled voluntary movement is first seen in .
explanation: The command for voluntary movement originates in cortical association areas, then planned in the cortex as well as in the basal ganglia and the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres. Hence, the neural activity first originates in the cortical association areas. The basal ganglia and cerebellum funnel information to the premotor and motor cortex by way of the thalamus. Motor commands from the motor cortex are relayed in large part via the corticospinal tracts to the spinal cord. Motor Association Area: Idea about voluntary movement Basal Ganglia: Planning and Organising the act Cerebellum( Neocerebellum) - Planning the act Premotor Cortex: Setting the posture before the act Primary Motor Cortex: Executing the act Spinocerebellum : Smoothening the act
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following descending motor tracts is essential for rapid skilled movement?
explanation: The lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal tracts are concerned with distal limb muscles and, with skilled voluntary movements. The ventral corticospinal tract and medial descending brainstem pathways (tectospinal, reticulospinal, and vestibulospinal tracts) are concerned with the axial muscles - postural adjustments and gross movements. Note: Medial portion of the ventral horn innervate proximal limb muscles, particularly the flexors. Lateral ventral horn innervates distal limb muscles.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true about experimental sham rage?
options: Is caused by removing the hypothalamus
explanation: Sham rage occurs in decorticate animals is the true statement. Sham rage is a controversial term used to describe behavior such as biting, clawing, hissing, arching the back and "violent alternating limb movements" produced in animal experiments by removing the cerebral cortex, which is claimed to occur in the absence of any sort of inner experience of rage. The reason for this might be that the removal of the neocortex causes a loss of inhibition of the areas involved in the rage reaction, causing those areas to become hyperactive (due to an uninhibited hypothalamus). Removal of hypothalamus abolishes the sham rage. Sham rage may be triggered by very mild stimuli such as weak touch. It is also non-goal directed.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A 62-year-old known hypertensive woman presented to the emergency with spasticity of both lower limbs. Further neurological examination showed regular, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of a muscle subjected to sudden, maintained stretch. Which of the following is false regarding this phenomenon?
options: Only sustained clonus with five or more beats is considered abnormal
Clonus may also occur in spinal cord injury that disrupts the descending cortical input to a spinal glycinergic inhibitory interneuron called the Renshaw cell
The stretch reflex–inverse stretch reflex sequence may contribute to this response
This is characteristic of states in which decreased -motor neuron discharge is present
explanation: The case scenario indicates clonus. A characteristic of states in which increased -motor neuron discharge is present is clonus. All the other options are correct. When a muscle is subjected to a sudden and maintained stretch, there occur regular, repetitive, and rhythmic contractions. This is called clonus. Ankle clonus is a typical example.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding a clasp knife effect is false?
explanation: Pacinian corpuscle is not involved in the clasp knife effect. When the muscles are hypertonic, the sequence of moderate stretch leads to muscle contraction, strong stretch leads to muscle relaxation. Eg. Passive flexion of the elbow meets immediate resistance due to stretch reflex in the triceps muscle. Further stretch activates the inverse stretch reflex. The resistance to flexion suddenly collapses, and the arm flexes. This sequence of resistance followed by a sudden decrease in resistance when a limb is moved passively is known as the clasp-knife effect because of its resemblance to the closing of a pocket knife. Lengthening reaction: When the tension on the muscle becomes extreme, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ leads to an instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
Fill in the blanks: Efferent axons from the dentate nucleus terminate in
thalamic nucleus and travel through peduncle?
explanation: Efferent axons from the dentate nucleus terminate in Ventral lateral nucleus of the thalamus (VL) and travel through superior cerebellar peduncle. The cerebellar cortex projects to the deep nuclei, which in turn project to the brainstem. The deep nuclei provide the only output for the spinocerebellum and the cerebrocerebellum: The medial spinocerebellum projects to the fastigial nuclei and from there to the brainstem. The adjacent hemispheric portions of the spinocerebellum project to the emboliform and globose nuclei and from there to the brainstem. The cerebrocerebellum projects to the dentate nucleus (Purkinje cells of cerebellum relay into this nucleus) and from there either directly or indirectly to the ventrolateral nucleus of the thalamus. These fibres pass through the cerebellar peduncles: The superior cerebellar peduncle includes fibers from deep cerebellar nuclei that project to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus. It also contains the ventral spinocerebellar tract fibers. The middle cerebellar peduncle contains only afferent fibers from the contralateral pontine nuclei. Inferior cerebellar peduncle a mixture of afferent fibers from the brainstem and spinal cord and efferent fibers to the vestibular nuclei.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following does not carry proprioceptive impulses?
explanation: The tecto cerebellar tract transmits only the auditory and visual impulses to the cerebellum. The olivocerebellar pathway projects to the cerebellar cortex via climbing fibers; the rest of the listed paths project via mossy fibers. question_text:
A patient has developed an inability to control the distance, speed, and range of motion necessary to perform smoothly coordinated movements. His finger-to-nose test and
heel-to-shin tests are abnormal. A lesion in which of the following sites is most likely to be found?
explanation: The given clinical findings are suggestive of dysmetria which is most commonly found due to a lesion involving the cerebellum or the cerebellar pathways. Therefore, a lesion in the spinocerebellar tract is most likely to be found in this patient. Dysmetria - In the absence of the cerebellum, the subconscious motor control system cannot predict how far movements will go. Therefore, the movements ordinarily overshoot their intended mark; then the conscious portion of the brain overcompensates in the opposite direction for the succeeding compensatory movement. Dysmetria also results from lesions in the spinocerebellar tracts because feedback information from the moving parts of the body to the cerebellum is essential for cerebellar timing of movement termination.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Dysdiadochokinesia refers to which of the following?
options: Inability to perform the Tandem-Gait test
Inability to stand without swaying with eyes open
Inability to perform rapid alternating movements with the hands
explanation: Dysdiadochokinesia—Inability to Perform Rapid Alternating Movements. In cerebellar lesions, the motor control system fails to predict where the different parts of the body will be at a given time. As a result, the succeeding movement may begin much too early or much too late and no orderly “progression of movement” can occur. So, a series of stalled attempted but jumbled movements occurs instead of the normal coordinated movements. This condition is called dysdiadochokinesia.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The patient exhibited an unsteady "drunk like" gait and the physician noted that he swayed while entering the examination room. Which region of the cerebellum was most likely affected by the bleed?
explanation: Flocculonodular Lobe is involved in the unsteady "drunk like" gait of the patient. Cerebellum has three parts based on function. Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): The oldest part of the cerebellum which contains nodulus in the vermis and the flanking flocculus. It has vestibular connections and is concerned with equilibrium and gait. Loss of it can cause disturbance of equilibrium and postural movements, especially during rapid movements. Spinocerebellum: The region that receives proprioceptive input from the body as well as a copy of the “motor plan” from the motor cortex. By comparing the plan with performance, it smooths and coordinates movements that are ongoing. Superior vermis is a part of spinocerebellum. Loss of it can cause problems with coordination. Cerebrocerebellum: They are the newest from a phylogenetic point of view, reaching their greatest development in humans. They interact with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The efferent fibres of the basal ganglia include which of the following?
explanation: The two major outputs/ efferents of the basal ganglia are from Globus pallidus interna and substantia nigra pars reticulata. Both are inhibitory (GABAergic) and both project to the ventrolateral and ventroanterior thalamus.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following describes a connection between components of the basal ganglia?
options: The subthalamic nucleus releases glutamate to excite the globus pallidus, internal segment.
The substantia nigra pars reticulata releases dopamine to excite the globus pallidus, external segment.
The striatum releases acetylcholine to excite the substantia nigra pars reticulata.
The globus pallidus, external segment releases glutamate to excite the striatum.
explanation: Intranuclear Connections: Dopaminergic nigrostriatal projection from the substantia nigra pars compacta to the striatum. GABAergic projection from the striatum to substantia nigra pars reticulata. There is an inhibitory (GABAergic) projection from the striatum to both GPe and GPi. The subthalamic nucleus receives an inhibitory input from GPe, and in turn the subthalamic nucleus has an excitatory (glutamate) projection to both GPe and GPi. From the ventrolateral thalamus, there is an excitatory (presumably glutamate) projection to the prefrontal and premotor cortex. This completes a full cortical-basal ganglia-thalamic-cortical loop.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding the functions of basal ganglia ?
options: Neurons in the basal ganglia, like those in the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres, discharge before movements begin.
The putamen circuit has its inputs mainly from the parts of the brain adjacent to the primary motor cortex but not much from the primary motor cortex itself.
The caudate nucleus plays a major role in this cognitive control of motor activity.
Substantia nigra pars reticulata is a major source of dopaminergic neurons to the corpus striatum.
explanation: Substantia nigra pars compacta (not pars reticulata) is the major source of dopaminergic neurons to the striatum. Neurons in the basal ganglia, like those in the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres, discharge before movements begin since the basal ganglia are involved in the planning and organization of skilled movements. The putamen circuit has its inputs mainly from the parts of the brain adjacent to the primary motor cortex. Then its outputs do go mainly back to the primary motor cortex and adjacent premotor cortex. it is mainly involved in complex motor activity and skilled movement. The caudate circuit plays a major role in the cognitive control of motor activity.
subject: Physiology

question_text: In a patient suffering from parkinsons's disease, what is the most likely reason behind the gradual decline in the therapeutic effect of L-dopa?
options: Inhibitory pathways grow into the basal ganglia from the frontal lobe.
There is an increase in circulating  -synuclein.
The dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra continue to degenerate.
explanation: The most likely reason behind the gradual decline in the therapeutic effect of L-dopa in a patient suffering from parkinsons's disease is the continued degeneration of the dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Since endogenous production of dopamine continues to decline, the exogenous source of dopamine (i.e. L-dopa) alone fails to maintain the same level of therapeutic effect. Parkinson's disease (Paralysis Agitans) was shown to result from the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta. The fibres to the putamen (part of the striatum) are most severely affected. Dopaminergic neurons and dopamine receptors are steadily lost with age in the basal ganglia in healthy individuals, and an acceleration of these losses apparently precipitates parkinsonism. Symptoms appear when 60–80% of the nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons degenerate.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
A 50-year-old gentleman who is a known patient of parkinson's disease, develops refractoriness to L-dopa therapy. An alternative treatment modality is being planned, which employs ablation of certain thalamic regions by neurosurgery. Which thalamic nucleus is the stereotaxic target for the neurosurgeons?
Centromedian
Ventrolateral
Ventroposterolateral
explanation: The ventrolateral thalamic nucleus is the stereotaxic target for the neurosurgeons to alleviate symptoms in Parkinson's disease refractory to levodopa. The two major outputs of the basal ganglia are from GPi and substantia nigra pars reticulata. Both are inhibitory (GABAergic) and both project to the ventrolateral and ventroanterior thalamus. From the thalamus, there is an excitatory (presumably glutamate) projection to the prefrontal and premotor cortex. This completes a full cortical-basal ganglia-thalamic-cortical loop. Therefore stereotactic ablation of ventrolateral thalamic nucleus helps in alleviation of symptoms in parkinson's disease refractory to levodopa. Basal Ganglia and Cerebellum

question_text: Which of the following is a nucleus of basal ganglia?
explanation: The basal ganglia has five nuclei on each side of the brain. question_text: Which part of the basal ganglia receives the afferent input?
explanation: The striatum receives the afferent input. Note: There are two main inputs to the basal ganglia: From the cerebral cortex (corticostriate pathway) and from the thalamus (thalamostriate pathway). They are both excitatory (glutamate) and they both terminate in the striatum. The two major outputs of the basal ganglia are from GPi and substantia nigra. Both are inhibitory (GABAergic) and both project to the thalamus. From the thalamus, there is an excitatory (glutamatergic) projection to the prefrontal and premotor cortex. This completes the cortical-basal ganglia-thalamic-cortical loop.

question_text: A patient is found to have a hemorrhage in the basal ganglia region. Which of the following is least likely to be affected in this patient?
explanation: This patient will have dysfunction of the basal ganglia. Maintenance of equilibrium is a function of the cerebellum and vestibular apparatus, hence will not be affected in this patient. explanation: Purkinje cells are the only output neurons (efferent neurons) from the cerebellar cortex. The Purkinje cells are the largest neurons in the cerebellum. question_text: Which of the following are climbing fibers?
explanation: Climbing fibers are olivocerebellar fibers. They originate from the inferior olivary nucleus. Climbing fibers and mossy fibers are the two main excitatory inputs to the cerebellum. Note: Mossy fibres provide direct input via the pontine nuclei. Climbing fibres Mossy fibres They come from one single s ource via the inferior olivary nuclei. They come from many source s and the fibers synapse with granule cells to form glomeru li. End on single Purkinje cells. Convey proprioceptive inputs from all over the body. Axons of granule cells bifurca te and form parallel fibers wh ich excite multiple Purkinje c ells.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is correct?
options: Spino cerebellum constitutes vermis and lateral portion of cerebellar hemisphere
Vestibulo cerebellum constitutes nodulus and flocculus
Vestibulo cerebellum constitutes lateral portion of cerebellar hemispheres
explanation: Vestibulocerebellum (archicerebellum) constitutes nodulus and flocculus and is hence called floculonodular lobe. Spinocerebellum (paleocerebellum) constitutes vermis and adjacent medial portions of cerebellar hemispheres. Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum) constitutes the lateral portions of hemispheres.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is a function of the neocerebellum?
options: Planning and programming of voluntary movements
explanation: The function of the neocerebellum is planning and programming of voluntary movements. The cerebellum can be divided into: The Vestibulocerebellum/Archicerebellum: Consists principally of the flocculonodular lobe and adjacent portions of the vermis. It participates in balance, vestibular reflexes, and eye movements. The Spinocerebellum/Paleocerebellum: Consists of most of the vermis plus the adjacent intermediate zones on both sides of the vermis. It coordinates movements of the limbs. Vermis: Proximal muscles, Intermediate zones: Distal muscles The Cerebrocerebellum/neocerebellum: Consists of the large lateral zones of the cerebellar hemispheres. It receives all its input from the cerebral cortex (motor, premotor and somatosensory). It transmits its output back to the brain, functioning in a feedback manner to plan sequential voluntary body and limb movements.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient with a cerebellar lesion will show all of the following features except:
explanation: A patient with a suspected cerebellar lesion will not have resting tremors. Resting tremors are characteristic features of basal ganglia lesions. (Parkinson's disease). Intentional tremors are seen in cerebellar diseases. Features of cerebellar disease Ataxia – Incoordinated, intermittent jerky movements with drunken gait. Hypotonia or atonia – Reduced or absence of muscle tone. Dysmetria – Inability to judge the force and range of movement resulting in past pointing. Dysdiadokokinesia – Failure to perform rapid alternating movements. Decomposition of movement – Lack of smooth flow of movement. Speech defect – Staccato speech or slurring speech. Pendular knee jerk (a feature of hypotonia). Intention tremors. Nystagmus (jerky movements of the eye). Rebound phenomenon.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The vestibulo-ocular reflex is being performed in a patient with vertigo. Which of the following is associated with this reflex?
explanation: The vestibulo-ocular reflex is controlled by the vestibulo-cerebellum, which constitutes the flocculonodular lobe.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Purkinje fibers are inhibitory for .
explanation: The input from the Purkinje cells to the deep nuclei is inhibitory. However, the deep nuclei output is always excitatory.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
explanation: The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly. Note: The input from the Purkinje cells to the deep nuclei is inhibitory. However, the deep nuclei output is always excitatory.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true?
options: Molecular layer contain stellate and basket cells
Molecular is the innermost layer of cortex
Axons of purkinje cell secrete Glutamate on deep cerebellar nuclei
explanation: The cerebellar cortex has three layers: External molecular layer: Contains Basket and Stellate Cells. Purkinje cell layer: Only one cell thick, containing the purkinje cells. Internal granular layer: Contains Granule and Golgi Cells
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following ascending pathways enters the cerebellum through the peduncle highlighted in green in the image?
explanation: The peduncle highlighted in the image is the superior cerebellar peduncle. The anterior spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through it and terminates in both sides of the cerebellum. Dorsal spinocerebellar tract enters the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle and terminates on the same side as its origin.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Concerning the circuitry between mossy fibers, climbing fibers and cells of the cerebellar cortex, which of the following pairs provide excitatory input?
options: Granule cell parallel fibers and mossy fibers
explanation: The excitatory fibers in the cerebellum are climbing fibers, mossy fibers, and granule cell parallel fibers. The fundamental circuits of the cerebellar cortex : Climbing fibers exert a strong excitatory effect on single Purkinje cells. Mossy fibers exert an excitatory effect on granule cells. Each granule cell sends an axon to the molecular layer, where the axon bifurcates to form a T. The branches of the T are straight and run long distances; thus, they are called parallel fibers. The parallel fibers form excitatory synapses on the dendrites of many Purkinje cells. The other neurons (basket cells, stellate cells, and golgi cells) are inhibitory interneurons. Basket cells and stellate cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and each inhibits many Purkinje cells. Golgi cells receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and mossy fibers. Their axons project to the dendrites of the granule cells where they form an inhibitory synapse. The output of the Purkinje cells is ultimately inhibitory to the deep cerebellar nuclei.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
Inhibition of Purkinje cells by stellate cells is an example of
Presynaptic inhibition
options: Stellate cells doesn’t inhibit purkinje cells
explanation: Inhibition of Purkinje cells by stellate cells is an example of feedforward inhibition. Mossy fibers exert a weak excitatory effect on many Purkinje cells via the granule cells. The granule cells also excite the basket and stellate cells via their parallel fibers. The basket and stellate cells, in turn, inhibit the Purkinje cells (Feed forward inhibition). Renshaw cells exhibit feedback inhibition. Hypothalamus and Limbic System
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true about thalamus?
options: Thalamus is the sensory gateway to cerebral cortex
Thalamus is the largest part of telencephalon
Y-shaped band of fibers divides the thalamus into 4 subdivisions
Thalamus is the motor gateway from the cortex
explanation: The thalamus is being called the sensory gateway to the cerebral cortex as all information that reaches the cortex is processed by the thalamus. The thalamus is a large collection of neuronal groups within the diencephalon; it participates in sensory, motor, and limbic functions. Other Options: Option B: Thalamus is the largest part of the diencephalon. Option C: Y shaped band of fibers divide the thalamus into 3 subdivisions- anterior, medial, and lateral group. Option D: Thalamus is the sensory gateway to the cortex.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which thalamic nuclei transmit pain?
explanation: The ventroposterior nuclear complex of the thalamus represents the main termination site for ascending somatosensory information (which includes pain) in the diencephalon. Thalamic nuclei have been divided into Specific (Relay) nuclei because they have a specific and selective relationship with a particular portion of neocortex Medial geniculate body for auditory information Lateral geniculate body is for information from retina Ventroposterior group for somatosensory information Nonspecific nuclei project to several cortical and subcortical regions
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is called ''the window of limbic system'' ?
explanation: The amygdala has been called the “window” through which the limbic system sees the place of the person in the world. The amygdala receives neuronal signals from all portions of the limbic cortex, as well as from the neocortex of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, especially from the auditory and visual association areas. Components of the limbic system The term limbic lobe, or limbic system, is applied to the part of the brain that consists of a rim of cortical tissue around the hilum of the cerebral hemisphere and a group of associated deep structures—the amygdala, the hippocampus, and the septal nuclei. The papez circuit is a closed neural circuitry that starts and ends in the hippocampus, which forms the basal ganglia. It is also known as the medial limbic circuit. The components of papez circuit are- Mnemonic-He Man Ate Cat He-Hippocampus Man-Mamillary body Ate-Anterior thalamus Cat-Cingulate gyrus
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is a component of the Papez circuit?
explanation: Anterior nucleus of the thalamus is a component of Papez circuit, which is important for short term memory. Papez Circuit (refer figure): The limbic system was studied by James Papez who described the Papez circuit. It consists of: Mnemonic for components of Papez circuit-He Man Ate Cat He-Hippocampus Man-Mamillary body Ate-Anterior thalamus Cat-Cingulate gyrus The fornix connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which are in turn connected to the anterior nuclei of the thalamus by the mammillothalamic tract. The anterior nuclei of the thalamus project to the cingulate cortex, and from there, connections to the hippocampus complete a complex closed circuit. The boundaries of the limbic system were subsequently expanded to include the amygdala, septum, basal forebrain, nucleus accumbens, and orbitofrontal cortex.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Stimulation of which of the following regions promotes a 'sense of reward' in human beings?
explanation: Major reward centres are located along the course of the medial forebrain bundle, especially in the lateral and ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus. Therefore, stimulation of those areas will promote a sense of reward. It is interesting to note that in the lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus, a weak stimulus produces a sense of pleasure whereas a strong stimulus produces rage. This phenomenon occurs in many areas where a weak stimulus produces a sense of reward while stronger ones produce a sense of punishment.
subject: Physiology

question_text: In response to an increase in plasma osmolality, ADH is released in blood. Which of the following sites contains the receptor to detect a change in plasma osmolality?
explanation: Osmoreceptors that detect any change in plasma osmolality and control ADH secrection, are located in anterior hypothalamus.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The main organ for biological clock is .
explanation: In the hypothalamus, the suprachiasmatic nucleus functions as the principal pacemaker, or time clock, for circadian rhythms. The pacemaker receives input from the eyes and many other parts of the nervous system, and these inputs mediate the effects exerted by the external environment (retinohypothalamic tract). One output of the pacemaker goes to the pineal gland, a gland within the brain that secretes the hormone melatonin.These neural signals cause the pineal gland to secrete melatonin during darkness but not during daylight.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following clinical features will be most likely seen in a patient with an anterior hypothalamic lesion?
explanation: Lesions involving the anterior and preoptic hypothalamic regions cause paradoxical vasoconstriction, tachycardia, and hyperthermia. The anterior hypothalamus activates mechanisms of cooling the body when the temperature increases via the reflex response. Stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus causes cutaneous vasodilation and sweating, thereby cooling the body. Lesions in this region cause hyperthermia, with rectal temperatures sometimes reaching 43°C (109.4°F).
subject: Physiology

question_text: Diurnal variation of ACTH is controlled by which of the following regions?
explanation: Diurnal variation of ACTH depend on suprachiasmatic nucleus. The secretory rates of ACTH and cortisol are high in the early morning but low in the late evening. This effect results from a 24-hour cyclical alteration in the signals from the suprachiasmatic nucleus of hypothalamus that cause cortisol secretion.When a person changes daily sleeping habits, the cycle changes correspondingly.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is not a function of the categorical hemisphere?
explanation: Functions of the categorical hemisphere are logical, analytical, sequential thinking, and verbal tasks, such as math, language forms, and philosophy. Human language functions depend more on one cerebral hemisphere than on the other. This hemisphere is concerned with categorization and symbolization and has often been called the dominant hemisphere. However, the other hemisphere is specialized in the area of spatiotemporal relations. The concept of “cerebral dominance” and a dominant and non-dominant hemisphere has been replaced by, one hemisphere for sequential-analytic processes (the categorical hemisphere) and one for visuospatial relations (the representational hemisphere). The representational cerebral hemisphere excels in nonlanguage skills, especially spatial perception, and artistic and musical talents.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Lesions in which nucleus of the hypothalamus produce a voracious appetite and rage?
options: Upper region of the lateral hypothalamus
explanation: A lesion in the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus, the satiety center, is responsible for producing a voracious appetite and rage. Lesions in the upper region of the lateral hypothalamus produce a profound loss of appetite.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Identify the site which is responsible for relieving pain when pressure is applied to the painful area.
explanation: It is a cross section of brain stem at pons. A is a periaqueductal gray matter which also consists of raphe nucleus. Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray matter inhibit transmission in nociceptive pathways. This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla (Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releases endogenous opiates. Other marked structures are B: Corticospinal tract C: Medial lemniscus D: Medial longitudinal fasciculus
subject: Physiology

question_text:
The factors that can cause a person to drink water due to stimulation of thirst mechanism is/are .
Dehydration
explanation: Dehydration, hemorrhage, and prandial drinking: All three can cause increased thirst resulting in water drinking. Increased osmolality acts via osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus. The decreased plasma volume, as in hemorrhage, acts via Renin-angiotensin system Baroreceptors in heart and blood vessels. The intake of liquids during a meal is known as prandial drinking. The increase is known as learned or habit response but is not understood completely. The following factors are thought to play a role Increase in plasma osmolality due to food absorption Action on hypothalamus by one or more gastrointestinal hormones Higher Mental Functions
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following statements about the reticular activating system is false?
options: Does not produce EEG alerting response
explanation: High-frequency stimulation of the midbrain reticular formation (the RAS) produces the EEG alerting response and arouses a sleeping animal. The Reticular Activating System (RAS) is a complex polysynaptic pathway arising from the brainstem reticular formation and hypothalamus with projections to the intralaminar and reticular nuclei of the thalamus which, in turn, project diffusely and nonspecifically to wide regions of the cortex including the frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital cortices. Collaterals funnel into it from the long ascending sensory tracts, the trigeminal, auditory, visual, and olfactory systems. The reticular formation plays an important role in determining the level of arousal; thus, it is called the ascending reticular activating system (ARAS).
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which is the EEG wave recorded in a subject who is awake but eyes closed?
explanation: A pha-waves are recorded best in the parieto-occipital region in adults at rest, i.e. awake but relaxed with eyes closed.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following structures regulates the sleep-wake cycle?
explanation: The hypothalamus and several non-specific nuclei in ascending reticular activating system (ARAS) located in the midbrain are involved in the regulation of the sleep-wake cycle. Sleep Centres Stimulation of the midbrain reticular formation (RAS) produces the EEG alerting response and promotes the waking state. The nucleus coeruleus (locus coeruleus) is rich in norepinephrine and the raphe nuclei of ARAS is rich in serotonin. These regions when stimulated induce wakefulness. The cholinergic neurons in the pontine reticular formation, on stimulation, induce sleep. Stimulation of the histaminergic neurons of the posterior hypothalamus produces arousal. Electrical stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus and the adjacent basal forebrain region rapidly induces sleep. This sleep-inducing effect is thought to be mediated by GABA-ergic inhibitory neurons. Orexin produced by hypothalamic neurons also appears to have a role in sleep-wake transition by regulating the changes in activity in these brainstem neurons. wakeful stat e Sleep Norepinephr ine Acetylcholi ne Serotonin GABA Histamine
subject: Physiology

question_text: In which stage of sleep are K complex and sleep spindles seen?
explanation: Stage 2 of NREM sleep is marked by the appearance of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (12–14 Hz) and occasional high-voltage biphasic waves called K complexes.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which stage constitutes the largest amount of sleep time of a young adult?
explanation: In young adults, the largest amount of sleep time (50–60%) is spent in stage 2 NREM sleep; REM phases constitute 20–25% of total sleep time, stages 3 and 4 NREM about 15–20%, and stage 1 non-REM about 5%. REM sleep occupies 80% of total sleep time in premature infants and 50 % in full-term neonates. In most adults, it is 25 %. In the elderly, it falls to about 20%.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is observed during sleep induction?
explanation: The cholinergic neurons in pontine reticular formation on stimulation, induce sleep. When the activity of norepinephrine and serotonin containing neurons (locus coeruleus and raphe nuclei) is dominant, there is a reduced level of activity in acetylcholine-containing neurons in the pontine reticular formation leading to wakefulness. The reverse of this pattern leads to REM sleep. A more even balance in the activity of these groups of neurons is associated with NREM sleep.
subject: Physiology

question_text: In NREM sleep, which part of brain is not involved?
explanation: The nucleus coeruleus (locus coeruleus) is rich in norepinephrine and the Raphe nuclei of ARAS is rich in serotonin. These regions when stimulated induce arousal. Thus, the dorsal raphe nucleus is not involved in NREM sleep. Genesis and Regulation of NREM sleep Electrical stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus and the adjacent basal forebrain region rapidly induces sleep mediated by GABA-ergic inhibitory neurons called the NREM-on cells. These cells are thought to produce sleep by inhibiting the histaminergic cells in the posterior hypothalamus as well as cells of the nucleus reticularis pontis oralis in the midbrain that mediate arousal. They are maximally active in NREM sleep and inactive during waking and REM sleep. NREM sleep is produced by synchronized synaptic potentials in cortical neurons generated by the rhythmic firing of thalamic relay neurons that project to the cortex. (Thalamocortical loop)
subject: Physiology

question_text: Delta waves are seen in
explanation: Delta waves are predominant in N3 (formerly called stage 3 and 4) of NREM. This is characteristic of deep sleep, also referred to as slow wave sleep. (Delta waves for Deep sleep)
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is associated with slow-wave sleep?
explanation: In slow-wave sleep, (Stages 3 and 4 of NREM) delta waves predominate the EEG.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is the source of melatonin?
explanation: Melatonin is released by the pineal gland (pinealocytes) that plays an important role in sleep mechanisms. In infants, the pineal gland is large and the cells are arranged in alveoli. It begins to involute before puberty and small concretions of calcium phosphate and carbonate appear (radiopaque structure) = physiological calcification.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A businessman who takes frequent long trips to overseas destinations visits the clinic asking for ''something that helps with falling asleep and adapt with the local time''. He is given a low dose of melatonin as a part of his treatment plan. Which of the following best describes its action?
explanation: Melatonin plays a key role in regulating the circadian rhythm. Therefore it is helpful in restoring the usual sleep wake pattern in patients with jetlag. Diurnal variation in melatonin secretion may function as a timing signal to coordinate events with the light-dark cycle in the environment (circadian rhythm). Melatonin synthesis and secretion are increased during the dark period of the day and maintained at low levels during the daytime. Increased melatonin levels induce sleepiness.
subject: Physiology

question_text: In which type of memory are basal ganglia involved?
explanation: Procedural memory includes skills and habits, which, once acquired, become unconscious and automatic. This type of memory is processed in the striatum. Implicit memory/Non-declarative memory: It does not require being conscious or awareness. E.g., Remembering how to brush your teeth. They are of 4 types: Procedural memory (skills and habits) in striatum, cerebellum, motor cortex Priming in neocortex Non-associative learning (includes habituation and sensitization, e.g., Byhearting facts) Associative learning: classical and operant conditioning Explicit/declarative memory: Memory of words,rules, language, etc. Associated with consciousness/awareness. E.g., recalling first day in school. They are of two types: Semantic memory (facts) e.g., Knowing capital of India: Parts of brain involved are tempora cortex and prefrontal cortex. Episodic memory (events) e.g., Recalling first day in college: hippocampus, medial temporal lobe and neocortex.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A 50-year-old lady develops severe anterograde amnesia. On further evaluation, a suprasellar craniopharyngioma invading adjacent structures is seen on T1-weighted MRI. Compression of which of the following structures can explain her symptoms?
explanation: Compression or a lesion affecting the mammillary body will cause anterograde amnesia. The Hippocampus, mammillary body and mammillothalamic tract are the primary structures involved in the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory. Any lesion involving this pathway will affect the ability to convert short-term memory to long-term memory, leading to anterograde amnesia.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following neural mechanism is not involved in synaptic plasticity and learning?
explanation: Sensitization is a neural mechanism involved in synaptic plasticity and learning (not desensitization). Neural basis of synaptic plasticity and learning Post-tetanic Potentiation Production of enhanced postsynaptic potential, which occurs after a brief tetanizing train of stimuli in the presynaptic neuron This enhancement lasts up to 60 seconds. Habituation A simple form of learning in which neutral stimulus is repeated many times until the subject becomes habituated to the stimulus and ignores it A classic example of non-associative learning (e.g., learning a fact by heart) Sensitization: The opposite of habituation Long-term Potentiation (LTP) A rapidly developing persistent enhancement of the post-synaptic potential response to presynaptic stimulation, after rapidly repeated stimulation of presynaptic neuron Characteristically observed in the hippocampus Long-term Depression Is the opposite of LTP Characterized by a decrease in synaptic strength Produced by slower stimulation of presynaptic neuron May be involved in the neural mechanism by which learning occurs in the cerebellum
subject: Physiology

question_text: The type of potentiation in hippocampus is
explanation: Long-term potentiation occurs in the hippocampus. LTP is a rapidly developing persistent enhancement of the post-synaptic potential response to presynaptic stimulation, after rapidly repeated stimulation of presynaptic neuron. NMDA receptors are involved in LTP.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Wernickes area is in
explanation: Wernicke’s area, lies behind the primary auditory cortex in the posterior part of the superior gyrus of the temporal lobe. Wernicke’s area is concerned with language comprehension.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is false about Broca’s aphasia?
explanation: Repetition is impaired in Broca’s aphasia. Aphasias are abnormalities of language functions that are not due to defects of vision or hearing or motor paralysis. They are caused by lesions in the categorical hemispheres.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A esion in the broca’s area will affect which of the following?
explanation: A esion in broca’s area will lead to an impairment of word-formation. Broca’s area is in the inferior frontal lobe. Broca area processes the information received from the wernicke area into a detailed and coordinated pattern for vocalization and then projects the pattern via a speech articulation area in the insula to the motor cortex. This then initiates the appropriate movements of the lips, tongue, and larynx to produce speech. The probable sequence of events that occurs when a subject names a visual object is shown in the figure and flowchart.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient is able to recognize a person by name but not face. Which of the following is the most likely site of the lesion?
explanation: This condition is prosopagnosia, which occurs in the lesions of the inferior occipitotemporal lobe. In humans, storage and recognition of faces are more strongly represented in the right inferior temporal lobe in right-handed individuals (i.e non-dominant inferior temporal lobe). Damage to this area can cause prosopagnosia, the inability to recognize faces. Patients with this abnormality can recognize people by their voices, body language, etc. However, they cannot identify the familiar people by seeing their faces. The left hemisphere is also involved, but the role of the right hemisphere is primary.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is the test for immediate memory?
options: Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed
Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps
Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed
Serial (20-1) subtraction test up to 5 steps
explanation: Forward digit span test is the best test among the given options. Memory is of 3 types: Immediate Recent Remote Immediate memory is attention dependent. Tests of attention and memory include Digit span test: Most important and best test for immediate memory Serial (100-7) subtraction test is the best for concentration Days of the week backwards Spell WORLD backwards (20–3) test Digit span test The examiner recites numbers randomly without any sequence and asks the patient to repeat the same. The examiner starts with a 2-number sequence and the digit span increases from 2 numbers to 3 numbers and so on. The patient is asked to repeat until he/she fails to repeat all numbers correctly. Digit forward Normally a person can repeat up to 7 digits (+/- 2) E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - ˜. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –˜. Digit backward Reproduction of longer digits in backward direction. Normally a person can repeat up to 5 digits (+/- 1) in backward direction (making option C wrong) Eg : Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - ˜. The person has to repeat it backwards. ˜ -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2. Serial (100-7) subtraction test 5 scores / steps are taken in to account 1st score – When the patient tells ˜3 (100 - 7 = ˜3) 2nd score - When the patient tells 86 (˜3 – 7 = 86) And so on . . 100 , ˜3 , 86 , 7˜ , 72 , 65 Hence among the given options : Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed would be the answer of choice as it is the best test for immediate memory

explanation: Sleep-related bruxism is diagnosed when an individual grinds or clenches the teeth during sleep. Bruxism occurs more commonly during NREM 2. Parasomnias refer to abnormal behavior or experiences that arise from or occur during sleep.

explanation: Bruxism occurs in stage 2 of NREM, whereas other sleep disorders given in the option occur in stage 3 of NREM

question_text: A 30-year-old male, who met with an RTA, regained consciousness after 36 hours. It was then discovered that the patient is unable to create new memories. Which of the following is the probable site of the lesion?
explanation: From the history, it is clear that the patient is suffering fron anterograde amnesia, most probably due to a lesion is hippocampus. Hippocampus is the primary structure within the temporal lobe involved in conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory. Hippocampal cognitive map is inappropriately reactivated during a deja vu experience. Hippocampus does not store memory but only converts short-term memory to long-term memory. Hence, hippocampal lesions cause only anterograde amnesia.

question_text: Which of the following is correctly paired to show the relationship between a brain area and a type of memory?
options: Medial temporal lobe and declarative memory
explanation: Declarative memory involves the hippocampus and the medial temporal lobe for retention. Priming - neocortex. Procedural memory - striatum. Associative learning- amygdala for its emotional responses and the cerebellum for the motor responses. Nonassociative learning - various reflex pathways.
