question_text: Arrange the following events in the sequence in which they occur, after 'p wave' in ECG:
explanation: The correct sequence of events that occur after the p-wave is 1-2-4-3, ie:- a wave in JVP  First heart sound  T wave in ECG  Rapid filling of ventricles. The sequence of the events in this question can be better understood with the following diagram: The p wave in the ECG represents atrial depolarization, which causes contraction of the atria, epresented by the 'a' wave in the JVP. Atrial contraction causes final filling of the ventricles (fourth phase of ventricular diastole) Atrial contraction is followed by the closure of the mitral valve, which causes the first-heart sound. This is followed by the isovolumetric contraction of the ventricle, which causes c wave in JVP, due to bulging of the tricuspid valve. This is followed by the rapid ejection phase of the ventricle. The T wave of ECG occurs during ventricular repolarization, which is followed by the opening of the mitral valve, followed by rapid filling phase of the ventricle (second phase of ventricula diastole). ’ote: Passive rapid filling occurs as the mitral valve opens just before atrial contraction occurs.

explanation: Korotkoffs sounds are due to arterial turbulence on occlusion of the vessel. The streamline flow in the unconstricted artery is silent. question_text: When measuring blood pressure, which of the following is unlikely to show a spuriously high BP?

question_text: During diastole, the arterial pressure is maintained by:
explanation: During diastole, the arterial pressure is maintained by the elastic recoil of aorta. There is stretching of aorta and arteries during systole due to ejection of blood from ventricle. During diastole, the previously stretched aorta and arteries recoil. The volume of blood that is displaced by the recoil furnishes continuous capillary flow throughout diastole.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The shape of arterial pulse is influenced by
explanation: The shape of arterial pulse is influenced by arterial wall expansion. Arterial Pulse The blood forced into the aorta during systole not only moves the blood in the vessels forward but also sets up a pressure wave that travels along the arteries. The pressure wave expands the arterial walls as it travels and the expansion is palpable as the pulse. The two major factors that influence arterial pulse are- stroke volume of the heart and distensibility (compliance) of the vessels.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to
explanation: The carotid sinus baroreceptor is most sensitive to pulse pressure. They fire more rapidly to a constantly changing pressure than a stationary one. Baroreceptors Stretch receptors located in the heart and adventitia of the blood vessels Types based on location Carotid sinus and aortic arch receptors (high-pressure regions) Cardiopulmonary receptors (low-pressure regions) Afferents Carotid sinus – a branch of Glossopharyngeal nerve (IX CN) – the carotid sinus nerve (sinus nerve of Hering) Aortic arch receptor – a branch of the Vagus nerve (X CN) – aortic depressor nerve Center for Reflex Medulla (Nucleus Tractus solitarius) Efferents Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart and vasculature Most sensitive to pulsatile pressure: They work to maintain BP in the range of mean BP, but it is the changes in the pressure they are the most sensitive to. The threshold for excitation: 50 mmHg Maximal activity: 180 mmHg Responses when one carotid sinus is isolated and perfused and the other baroreceptors are denervated Perfusion pressure <30mm Hg:no response 70–110mm Hg: the linear relationship between perfusion pressure and the fall in systemic BP and HR >150mm Hg: no further increase in response to the degree of inhibition of the sympathetic nerve is maximal.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Baroreceptor stimulation would result in
explanation: Baroreceptor stimulation would result in decreased sympathetic discharge to heart. The baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels. Baroreceptor stimulation, by distension of the structures they are located in, inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart. Thus leading to: Vasodilation and venodilation Hypotension Bradycardia Decrease in cardiac output
subject: Physiology

question_text: The maximum blood pressure to which carotid baroreceptors respond is
explanation: The maximum blood pressure to which carotid baroreceptors respond is 180 mmHg (arterial pressure here and not MAP). The blood pressure range to which carotid baroreceptors respond is 70- 150 mmHg of mean arterial pressure.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Discharge from Baroreceptors cause inhibition of:
explanation: Discharge from Baroreceptors cause inhibition of Rostral ventrolateral medulla. The baroreceptors are stimulated by distension of the structures in which they are located. Their afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves to the medulla. These fibers release glutamate to excite neurons in the nucleus of the tractus solitarius (NTS). These NTS neurons then excite neurons in the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM). These CVLM neurons release the inhibitory neurotransmitter -aminobutyric acid (GABA) into the RVLM to reduce the firing rate of these. Thus, reducing the sympathetic outflow.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Baroreceptor provides
explanation: Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure. Increased baroreceptor discharge inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart. Baroreceptor reflex Increased BP  stimulation of baroreceptors  stimulation of NTS  inhibition of RVLM  inhibition of sympathetic system Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC  parasympathetic stimulation Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation  decreased HR and BP NTS - Nucleus tractus solitarius CVC - Cardiovagal center RVLM - Rostral ventrolateral medulla HR- Heart rate BP - Blood pressure
subject: Physiology

question_text: Afferent fibers from baroreceptors for blood pressure control goes to?
explanation: Afferent fiber for blood pressure control goes to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS). Increased BP stimulates the baroreceptors which provide negative feedback in response to the increase in blood pressure. Baroreceptor reflex: Increased BP  stimulation of baroreceptors  stimulation of NTS  excitation of CVLM  inhibition of RVLM  inhibition of sympathetic system Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC  parasympathetic stimulation Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation  decreased HR and BP NTS - Nucleus tractus solitarius CVC - Cardiovagal centre CVLM - Caudal ventrolateral medulla RVLM - Rostral ventrolateral medulla HR - Heart rate BP - Blood pressure
subject: Physiology

question_text: The low pressure receptors are
options: Stimulated by atrial systole and diastole
explanation: The low-pressure receptors are stimulated by atrial systole and diastole The low-pressure receptors are those in the great veins, right and left atria and pulmonary vessels. Atrial stretch receptors are of two types: Type A: discharge primarily during atrial systole Type B: discharge primarily during late diastole Distension of the atrial wallsstimulation of atrial receptors  Vasodilation, fall in BP and increased heart rate.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Occlusion of common carotid arteries on both sides leads to
options: Increase in heart rate and BP
Increase in BP and decrease in heart rate
Decrease in heart rate and BP
No effect on heart rate and BP
explanation: Occlusion of both common carotid arteries causes an increase in HR and BP. Reduced sinus pressure  response carried to nucleus tractus solitarius via glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve  less inhibitory effect on the vasomotor center. This leads to: Decreased parasympathetic activity to the heart - Increases heart rate Increased sympathetic activity to the heart and blood vessels - Increases heart rate, contractility, constricts arterioles - Increases TPR, constricts veins - increases venous return Note: The carotid baroreceptors are located in the walls of the carotid sinus, which is located at or slightly above the bifurcation of the common carotid arteries. So, the occlusion of common carotid arteries is occlusion proximal to the carotid sinus. If the occlusion is distal to the carotid sinus increase in sinus pressure  activation of baroreceptor reflex  decrease in BP and HR.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is
explanation: The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is Angiotensin II. Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor that increases the total peripheral resistance and decreases Na+ and H2O excretion by kidney, thereby causing an increase in arterial BP.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Marey’s law states that
options: Heart rate varies directly with blood pressure
Heart rate varies inversely with blood pressure
Heart rate do not have any relation with blood pressure
Heart rate is directly proportional to cardiac output
explanation: Marey’s law states that the heart rate varies inversely with blood pressure.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is NOT caused by sympathetic stimulation?
explanation: Increased venous capacitance is NOT caused by sympathetic stimulation. Important effects of increased sympathetic stimulation: Arteriolar vasoconstriction Increased stroke volume Increased heart rate Venoconstriction and decrease in venous capacitance The increase in mean systemic filling pressure is caused mainly by venous contraction. All these effects together bring about an increased arterial pressure.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding nitric oxide?
explanation: Nitric oxide acts by increasing cGMP not by increasing cAMP. Nitric Oxide Also known as Endothelium-derived relaxing factor (EDRF). Synthesized in endothelial cells from arginine in a reaction catalyzed by nitric oxide synthase (NOS). Mechanism of action: NO causes activation of guanylyl cyclase   cGMP  relaxation of vascular smooth muscle  vasodilation. Effects of NO: Vasodilation. Neuromodulator in brain. Antimicrobial and cytotoxic activity of various inflammatory cells. In GIT, relaxation of smooth muscle. Penile erection.
subject: Physiology

question_text: All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except
explanation: Endothelin-1 Potent vasoconstrictor agent. Produced by endothelial cells. They are secreted locally and act in a paracrine fashion. Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1) Potent vasoconstrictor. Platelet activation. Inotropic effect. Closure of ductus arteriosus. Have a role in the pathogenesis of hypertension, myocardial infarction, and congestive heart failure. In the brain, regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB). In the kidneys, they are involved in tubuloglomerular feedback  GFR. In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors). In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads t Hirschsprung’s/megacolon). Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 genecraniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to his primary-care clinician complaining of erectile dysfunction. He is given a prescription for sildenafil, and on follow-up, reports that his ability to sustain an erection has been improved markedly by this treatment. The action of which of the following vasoactive mediators would primarily be prolonged in this patient?
explanation: The action of nitric oxide would primarily be prolonged in this patient. Sildenafil: It is used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, which inhibits cGMP-specific phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5), an enzyme that degrades cGMP, thereby effectively prolonging the action of NO. Penile erection is produced by release of nitric oxide (NO), with consequent vasodilation and engorgement of the corpora cavernosa.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
explanation: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge Reflex. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation. Other options: Option A: Bezold–Jarisch Reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causes profound bradycardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing. Option C: Cushing Reflex: When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration. Option D: J Reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) causes apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and suffered a head injury. On examination, he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible for elevated blood pressure in this condition?
explanation: The reflex responsible for elevated blood pressure(BP) in head injury patients is the Cushing reflex. When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla. Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms: Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors) Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure) Irregular respiration (bradypnea)
subject: Physiology

question_text: All of the following are rapidly acting blood pressure control mechanisms except:
explanation: Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is not a rapidly acting pressure control mechanism, it is an intermediate-acting mechanism. Regulation of Arterial Blood Pressure: Rapidly acting pressure control mechanism (acting within sec or min) The chemoreceptor reflex. The central nervous system ischemic mechanism. The baroreceptor reflex. Intermediate-acting mechanisms (act after minutes) The capillary fluid shift mechanism. Stress-relaxation of the vasculature. The renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism. Long-term mechanisms (after days) Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) Note: Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is an intermediate-acting mechanism, but water conservation by RAAS is a long-term mechanism in the regulation of BP. Most rapidly acting: Baroreceptor reflex>>Chemoreceptor reflex
subject: Physiology

options: Glutamate is released by Caudal Ventrolateral Medulla (CVLM) neurons projecting to the intermediolateral nucleus (IML)
GABA is released by Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) neurons projecting to the nucleus ambiguus
GABA is released by CVLM neurons projecting to the Rostral Ventrolateral Medulla (RVLM)

question_text: Stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors causes:
explanation: Peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies can produce variable effects on heart rate- Direct Effect vagal stimulation  bradycardia Indirect effect Hypoxia peripheral chemoreceptor stimulation hyperventilation and increased catecholamine secretion  tachycardia and increased cardiac output Chemoreceptor reflex Receptors Peripheral chemoreceptors in carotid and aortic bodies Central chemoreceptors in the medulla Stimulus decrease in- PaO2 increase in-Pa CO2, H+ ion conc Afferent IX (sinus nerve of Hering) and X (vagus N) Center for reflex Medulla Efferent Sympathetic and parasympathetic neurons to heart vasculature and adrenal medulla Response Direct effect- bradycardia Indirect effect- hyperventilation, tachycardia, vasoconstriction, increased cardiac output and increased BP
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex?
explanation: Serotonin can be responsible for Bezold–Jarisch reflex. Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers located in the cardiopulmonary region (ex: ventricles, atria, great veins, pulmonary artery, juxtacapillary region of alveoli) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This response is called Bezold-Jarisch reflex. Other substances that can cause Bezold–Jarisch reflex are capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing?
Decrease in firing from baroreceptor
options: Vagal output to cardiac fibres increase
explanation: There is a decreased firing from the baroreceptors. When a person stands up from a lying down position, it causes pooling of the blood in the legs, due to gravity. This reduces the venous return and causes a decrease in cardiac output. Reduced cardiac output, leads to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn causes reduced firing from baroreceptors. As a result, the vagal tone is suppressed leading to increased heart rate. Gastrointestinal Secretion and Gastrointestinal Hormones
subject: Physiology

explanation: Ptyalin (salivary  -amylase) is secreted by the salivary gland. There are 3 pairs of salivary glands Parotid Submandibular Sublingual glands Functions of saliva:

question_text: Which of the following statements is false?
options: Meissner’s plexus is present in submucosa
Myentric plexus is present between inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layer
Muscularis mucosa is associated with peristalsis
Villi are absent in large intestin
explanation: Muscularis propria is associated with peristalsis and not muscularis mucosa. Contraction of muscularis mucosa alters absorptive and secretive surface area. Meissner’s plexus (submucosal plexus) is present in the submucosa. The myenteric plexus (Auerbach plexus) is present between the inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layer. Villi are absent in the large intestine but present in the small intestine. Layers of intestinal wall from outside to inside are as follows: Serosa The longitudinal smooth muscle layer The circular smooth muscle layer Submucosa Mucosa
subject: Physiology

question_text: Salivary amylase is inactivated by which of the following?
explanation: Salivary amylase is inactivated by the low pH of the stomach. It is rapidly denatured at pH 4 (gastric pH is 1 to 3.5). Salivary amylase is activated by chloride. Salivary  amylase (Ptyalin): Digests starch: cleaves internal  -1,4-glycosidic bonds in starch Optimum pH: 7 Denatured at pH 4 Since a large portion of a meal often remains unmixed for a considerable length of time in the stomach, the salivary enzyme may account for the digestion of as much as 75% of the starch present before it is denatured by gastric acid. Note: Even in the absence of salivary amylase, there is no defect in carbohydrate digestion because pancreatic amylase is sufficient to digest all of the ingested starch.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following gland secretes lingual lipase?
explanation: Lingual lipase is secreted by von Ebner’s gland. von Ebner's gland is a serous salivary gland situated around circumvallate and foliate papillae in front of the terminal sulcus. Lingual lipase hydrolyse dietary lipid. The optimal pH is 3-6. Unlike pancreatic lipase, it is not inhibited by bile salts, medium-chain FA, and lecithin. Hence, it remains active through the stomach and into the intestine.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following fluids have the highest daily secretion of potassium?
explanation: The highest daily secretion of K+ is into the saliva. In the process of formation of saliva, Na+ and Cl- are reabsorbed from the saliva, and K+ and HCO3- are secreted into the saliva. Note: The highest concentration of K+ is in the rectal fluid.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland causing a patient to salivate, pass through which of the following ganglions?
explanation: The secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland pass through the Otic ganglion. Salivary secretion is almost entirely controlled by the parasympathetic nervous system. Volume is mainly mediated by parasympathetic stimulation while the composition of saliva (increased proteinaceous content) is slightly modified by sympathetic input. The parasympathetic preganglionic fibers are delivered by the glossopharyngeal and facial nerves to otic and submandibular ganglion respectively. Regulation of salivary secretion by the parasympathetic nervous system:

question_text: Rennin is present in
explanation: Rennin is present in the gastric juice. It is also called chymosin. It is a protein-digesting enzyme (endopeptidase) found in the stomach of newborn cows. It transforms (curdles) caseinogen into insoluble casein. In humans and in some animals that lack rennin, milk is coagulated by the action of pepsin. Note: Renin is produced by juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney, which hydrolyzes angiotensinogen to angiotensin I.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient presents with anemia and achlorhydria. After evaluation, pernicious anemia is diagnosed. Damage to which of the following cells is responsible for this condition?
explanation: Pernicious anemia develops due to autoimmune damage to the parietal cells in gastric glands. The parietal cells secrete both HCl and intrinsic factor. Therefore, when the parietal cells are destroyed, both achlorhydria, as well as pernicious anemia, develop. Pernicious anemia occurs due to the deficiency of the intrinsic factor of Castle, which is important for the absorption of vitamin B12.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is secreted by the Goblet cells?
explanation: Goblet cells secrete mucus. These cells are located on the surface of the crypts of Lieberkuhn and the villi of the small intestine. Cells present in the crypts of Lieberkuhn: Goblet cells (similar to surface cells of the stomach) - secrete mucus that acts as a lubricant and protects the intestinal surfac Epithelial cells - secrete succus entericus (intestinal secretion) Paneth cells - secrete lysozymes and defensins (antibacterial substances)
subject: Physiology

question_text: In the stomach, H+ ions are secreted in exchange for which of the following ions?
explanation: H+ ions are secreted into the lumen of the stomach in exchange for K+ by the H+–K+ pump (H+, K+-ATPase). Mechanism of HCl formation: In the parietal cells, CO2 and H2O are converted to H+ and HCO3–, catalyzed by carbonic anhydrase. H+ is secreted into the lumen of the stomach by the H+–K+ pump in exchange for K+. HCO3– moves out of the cell into the bloodstream in exchange for Cl– (Cl––HCO3–exchange). This Cl– moves into the lumen of the stomach. H+ and Cl– combine to form HCl. As HCO3– is added to the venous blood, the pH of the blood increases. This is called alkaline tide. Eventually, this HCO3– will be secreted in the pancreatic secretions to neutralize H+ in the small intestine. Proton pump inhibitors inhibit H+–K+ pump.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease is found to have excess gastric secretion. All of the following are likely to increase the secretion, except:
explanation: Gastric secretion is not increased by HCl. HCl decreases gastric secretion via a negative feedback mechanism. Low pH due to HCl in the stomach inhibits gastrin secretion, which in turn, inhibits H+ secretion. Hence, the presence of HCl inhibits gastric secretion. Stimuli that increase acid and gastrin secretion: Distension of stomach Peptides Calcium Alcohol and caffein Increased vagal discharg Stimuli that decrease acid and gastrin secretion: Gastric acid Secretin family - secretin, glucagon, VIP, GIP Somatostatin CCK, Calcitonin PGE2
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient with recurrent abdominal pain is found to have multiple duodenal ulcers. After a detailed evaluation, he is diagnosed with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Stimulation of which of the following can inhibit gastric secretion in this patient?
explanation: Gastric secretion is inhibited by somatostatin. It inhibits gastric secretion via both direct and indirect pathways: Direct pathway - somatostatin acts directly on the acid-producing parietal cells by binding to receptors on parietal cells that are coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gi protein. This inhibits adenylyl cyclase, and cAMP levels are reduced. In this way, somatostatin antagonizes th stimulatory effect of histamine on H+ secretion. Indirect pathway - somatostatin inhibits the release of histamine and gastrin and thus decreasing H+ secretion indirectly.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Maximum gastric secretion occurs in which of the following phases?
options: Secretion is equal in all phases
explanation: Maximum gastric secretion occurs in the gastric phase.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is responsible for increasing the HCl secretion in the gastric phase?
explanation: HCl secretion in the gastric phase is increased by gastrin. Gastrin stimulates H+ secretion by interaction with cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cell which secretes HCl.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true about the secretion from the exocrine pancreas?
explanation: Pancreatic secretion is stimulated by cholecystokinin (CCK) and Ach. It is always isotonic. It has virtually the same Na+ and K+ concentrations as in plasma. It is rich in several digestive enzymes like amylase, trypsin, chymotrypsin, lipase, elastase, etc.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice is secreted under the influence of which of the following stimulants?
explanation: Bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice is secreted under the influence of secretin. Secretin is secreted by the S cells of the duodenum. Its primary function is to promote the secretion of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice by the ductal cells of the pancreas and duodenum. This secretion is poor in enzymes. Other functions: Augments the effects of CCK Inhibits gastrin releas Decreases gastric acid secretion Contraction of the pyloric sphincter Exerts trophic effect on the pancreas
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which among the following is the most alkaline secretion?
explanation: The most alkaline secretion is Brunner’s gland secretion with a pH of 8.0 – 8.9. Brunner’s gland is located in the first few centimeters of the duodenal wall. It secretes large amounts of alkaline mucus in response to tactile stimuli on the duodenal mucosa, vagal stimulation, and GI hormones, especially secretin. It is inhibited by sympathetic stimulation. The function of the mucus secreted by Brunner’s glands is to protect the duodenal wall from digestion by the highly acidic gastric juice emptying from the stomach. Note: The second most alkaline secretion in the GI tract is the pancreatic juice.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is the most potent choleretic?
explanation: Bile salts (chemical choleretic) are the most potent choleretics. Any substance that increases bile secretion is called a choleretic. Bile secretion may be increased by chemical (bile salts), hormonal (Secretin), and neural (vagal stimulation) mechanisms. Note: Cholagogues cause contraction of the gallbladder. Eg. CCK
subject: Physiology

question_text: Primary bile acids are synthesized from
explanation: Primary bile acids are synthesized from cholesterol by hepatocytes. Bile contains bile acids, bile salts, bile pigments, phospholipids, water, and electrolytes. It is secreted by the liver and concentrated in the gall bladder. Two primary bile acids (cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid) are synthesized from cholesterol by hepatocytes. When these primary bile acids are secreted into the lumen of the intestine, a portion of each is converted to secondary bile acids (deoxycholic acid and lithocholic acid) by bacteria. The liver conjugates primary and secondary bile acids with glycine or taurine to their respective bile salts. Ex: Glycocholic acid, Taurodeoxycholic acid. Rate of bile secretion is 30 - 60 mL/hour (500 - 1000 mL/day). Note: Bile has no digestive enzymes.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of
explanation: Enterohepatic circulation is necessary for the secretion of bile salts. The enterohepatic circulation of bile salts is the recycling of bile salts between the small intestine (terminal ileum) and the liver by means of the portal vein. It occurs 6-8 times a day. The recirculation of bile salts to the liver reduces the demand to synthesize new bile salts.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following does not belong to the secretin family?
explanation: CCK (Cholecystokinin) belongs to the gastrin family, not the secretin family. Classification of GI hormones based on structure and function: Gastrin family - Gastrin, Cholecystokinin Secretin family - Secretin, Glucagon, VIP, GIP Others - Motilin, Ghrelin, Somatostatin, etc
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient underwent resection of the gastric antrum. A few weeks later, endoscopy revealed atrophy of the gastric mucosa. Serum levels of gastrin were found to be decreased. Which of the following is true regarding this GI hormone?
explanation: Gastrin is a peptide hormone. It is secreted by the G cells of the gastric mucosa present in the antrum of the stomach, primarily during the gastric phase of gastric acid secretion. It causes gastric secretion at 1000-1500 mL/day. Its primary stimulus is gastric distension. Primary functions of Gastrin: Gastric acid (HCl) secretion Pepsin secretion Trophic action on the gastric mucosa Other functions: Stimulates gastric motility Prevents gastroesophageal reflux by contraction of LES Conditions associated with increased gastrin secretions (Ex: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome), will cause an increase in H+ secretion and hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa. Conditions associated with reduced gastrin secretion (Ex: Resection of the gastric antrum), will cause a decrease in H+ secretion and atrophy of the gastric mucosa.
subject: Physiology

question_text: What is the effect of cholecystokinin on GIT?
explanation: Cholecystokinin (CCK) inhibits gastric emptying. It is secreted by the I cells of the duodenal and jejunal mucosa in response to monoglycerides, fatty acids, and amino acids. Primary functions: Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion Contraction of the gallbladder Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi Other functions: Augmentation of the action of secretin in producing alkaline (bicarbonate rich) pancreatic juic Inhibition of gastric emptying Trophic (growth) effect on the exocrine pancreas Increases the synthesis of enterokinas It enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon Along with secretin, it augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter and thus preventing th reflux of duodenal contents into the stomach It promotes satiety

question_text: What stimulates secretin secretion?
explanation: Secretin secretion is stimulated by acid. Stimuli that increase secretin secretion: Low duodenal pH (2-4.5) due to acid in the chym Products of protein digestion in the upper small intestin Secretin secretion is regulated by negative feedback:

question_text: Salivary amylase is activated by which of the following ions?
explanation: Salivary amylase is activated by Cl-. Human salivary and pancreatic amylases are activated by chloride (Cl–). They have optimum activities near-neutral pH (7.4). They hydrolyze internal 1:4 linkages but spare 1:6 linkages and terminal 1:4 linkages in starch.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Where does the digestion of disaccharides occur?
explanation: Digestion of disaccharides occurs in the small intestine. The enzymes maltase, sucrase, isomaltase, lactase, and trehalase are located in the enterocytes covering the intestinal microvilli brush border. The disaccharides are digested into their constituent monosaccharides as they come in contact with these enterocytes.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The mechanism by which glucose is absorbed in the intestine is:
explanation: Glucose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport. On the basolateral side, there is active transport of sodium ions out of the cell into the interstitial fluid. This depletes sodium inside the cell. Because of this Na+ concentration difference, more Na+ binds to the SGLT on the luminal side. This increases the affinity of SGLT for glucose and glucose binds to it. Then, both the Na+ and glucose are transported together to the interior of the cell. Thus, glucose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport. The energy for glucose transport is provided indirectly, by the active transport of Na+ out of the cell. The glucose moves out of the cell into the blood across the basolateral membrane by facilitated diffusion mediated via GLUT.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is a true statement?
options: Fructose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport
SGLT2 is involved in absorption of monosaccharide in intestine
GLUT2 is involved in transport of glucose from enterocyte into interstitium
GLUT4 is responsible for basal glucose uptake in many organ
explanation: GLUT2 is involved in the transport of glucose from the enterocyte into the interstitium (or out of the enterocytes). The image below shows the function of GLUT 2 on enterocytes. Option A: Fructose absorption is through facilitated diffusion from the intestinal lumen into the enterocyte by GLUT5 and out of the enterocytes into the interstitium by GLUT2. Option B: SGLT1 is involved in the absorption of glucose into the enterocyte. SGLT2 is responsible for glucose transport out of the renal tubules. Option D: GLUT1 is responsible for basal glucose uptake in many organs.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is the main enzyme involved in the hydrolysis of 1,6 linkage of starch?
explanation: The main enzyme involved in the hydrolysis of 1,6 linkage of starch is isomaltase. Both salivary and the pancreatic  -amylases hydrolyze internal 1:4 linkages but spare 1:6 linkages and terminal 1:4 linkages of starch.
subject: Physiology

question_text: What is chymotrypsinogen?
explanation: Chymotrypsinogen is a zymogen. çymogens (proenzymes) are inactive precursors of the enzymes. Most of the peptidases (proteases) are present in the form of proenzymes. Trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen, proelastase, procarboxypeptidase A, procarboxypeptidase B are zymogens.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following processes converts trypsinogen to trypsin?
options: Removal of a few amino acid
explanation: Trypsinogen is converted to trypsin by the removal of a few amino acids. All proenzymes are converted to their active form by selective proteolysis (removal of a few amino acids). Enterokinase cleaves trypsinogen to yield active trypsin. It is located on the brush border of duodenal enterocytes.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following protects the normal pancreas from autodigestion?
explanation: The synthesis and secretion of proteases as catalytically inactive proenzymes protect the normal pancreas from autodigestion. All the protease proenzymes present in the pancreatic juice get converted to their active form only in the small intestinal lumen (site of action). If proenzymes get activated in the pancreas (site of origin), they can digest the entire pancreas within a few hours, giving rise to the condition called acute pancreatitis.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is not an endopeptidase?
explanation: Carboxypeptidase is an exopeptidase, not endopeptidase. Peptidases (proteases) are of two types: Endopeptidases - they act at interior peptide bonds in the peptide molecules. Ex- pepsin, trypsin, chymotrypsin, elastase. Exopeptidases - they hydrolyze the amino acids at the carboxyl ends of the polypeptides, one at a time. Ex- carboxypeptidase, aminopeptidase.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Peptide transporter 1 is involved in the absorption of which of the following?
explanation: Peptide transporter 1 (PepT1) is involved in the absorption of the dipeptide. The dipeptides and tripeptides are transported along with H+ into enterocytes by a system known as peptide transporter 1 (PepT1). These peptides undergo intracellular hydrolysis to release amino acids. These amino acids are absorbed into the circulation from the basolateral membrane via basolateral amino acid transporter. H+ moves out of the cell via Na+-H+ exchanger on the luminal side.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is passively absorbed in the gut?
explanation: Lipids are passively absorbed in the gut. The products of lipid digestion (monoglycerides and free fatty acids) are incorporated into micelles that are formed by bile salts and diffuse across the intestinal epithelium. Short and medium-chain fatty acids can directly diffuse across the intestinal epithelium. Note: Recent evidence suggests that specific carrier proteins (membrane transporters) may be involved in the transport of long-chain fatty acids.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria are maximally absorbed in which part of the intestine?
explanation: Short-chain fatty acids produced by bacteria are absorbed maximally in the colon by secondary active transport. Almost all the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Folate is absorbed in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum). Maximum water absorption takes place in the jejunum.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is not a function of short-chain fatty acids in the colon?
options: Trophic effect on the colonic epithelial cell
explanation: Short-chain fatty acids (2–5-carbon) in the colon promote the absorption of Na+, not secretion. Short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) in the colon are formed by the action of colonic bacteria on complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and other components of the dietary fiber i.e the material that escapes digestion in the upper gastrointestinal tract and enters the colon. Functions: Exert a trophic effect on the colonic epithelial cell Combat inflammation Helps in maintaining acid-base equilibrium
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following patients is most likely to have a major electrolyte imbalance?
options: A patient with duodenal resection due to a primary tumor
A patient who underwent jejunal resection due to an obstruction
A patient with ileal resection due to recurrent Crohn's disease
A patient with sigmoid resection due to a recurrent fistula
explanation: The resection of jejunum leads to major electrolyte imbalance because most of the fluid and electrolyte reabsorption occurs in this segment. The maximum water absorption takes place in the jejunum. The amount of water absorbed in the intestines follows this order: Jejunum > Ileum > Colon. Almost all the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Folate is absorbed in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum).
subject: Physiology

question_text: What is the amount of fluid absorbed in the intestine in a day?
explanation: The amount of fluid absorbed in the intestine in a day is around 8L. About 2L of ingested water and 7L of various secretions enter the gastrointestinal tract. Out of this, the majority (8800 mL) is absorbed in the small intestine and colon. The small remaining volume that is not absorbed (100–200 mL) is excreted in feces.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is not absorbed in the colon?
explanation: K+ is not absorbed in the colon. It is secreted in the rectal fluid. Electrolytes (Na+, Cl-), short-chain fatty acids (acetate, propionate, butyrate), and water are absorbed in the colon.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is false about vitamin absorption?
options: Fat-soluble vitamin digestion needs cholesterol esterase
Vitamin B12 is absorbed in ileum
Folate is absorbed by carriers that are Na+ cotransporter
Most vitamins are absorbed in upper small intestine
explanation: Folate and vitamin B12 absorption is Na+-independent. The remaining water-soluble vitamins—thiamin, riboflavin, niacin, pyridoxine, pantothenate, biotin, and ascorbic acid are absorbed by carriers that are Na+ cotransporters. Option A: Fat-soluble vitamins are ingested in the form of esters. Digestion needs hydrolysis by cholesterol esterase and absorbed after incorporating into micelles. Options B and D: Most vitamins are absorbed in the upper small intestine, but vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach. This complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa.
subject: Physiology

question_text: A patient with anemia is prescribed iron tablets. The absorption of the supplement is likely to take place in which part of the intestine?
explanation: Almost all the iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Most of the iron in the diet is in the ferric (Fe3+) form, whereas it is the ferrous (Fe2+) form that is absorbed. Note: Carbohydrates, proteins, lipids are absorbed throughout the length of the small intestine. Bile acids are present throughout the small intestine, but active absorption occurs only in the ileum, and active absorbtion of folate occurs in the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum).
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following stimulates ferritin synthesis?
explanation: Elemental iron stimulates ferritin synthesis. It synthesizes ferritin by causing the release of a cytoplasmic protein that binds to a specific region in the ferritin mRNA. This disruption activates ferritin mRNA and results in its translation. Hepcidin binds to ferroportin and triggers its internalization and degradation. This results in decreased iron absorption and decreased circulating iron levels which reduces ferritin synthesis. Note: Ferritin sequesters Fe2+, a potentially toxic molecule.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is inhibited by hepcidin?
explanation: Hepcidin inhibits iron absorption. It is named for its originally described property as a hepatocellular protein with bactericidal activities. Iron metabolism is regulated by hepcidin, a protein and acute phase reactant produced by the liver. It binds to ferroportin and degrades it. This inhibits the transfer of iron from the enterocyte to the plasma via ferroportin. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells (enterocytes) in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are shed off.
subject: Physiology

question_text: While prescribing iron to a patient with iron deficiency anemia, which of the following would you recommend to increase its absorption?
explanation: Ascorbic acid is given with iron to increase its absorption. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) forms soluble complexes with iron and reduces iron from the ferric to the ferrous state, thereby enhancing iron absorption. Option A: Milk decreases iron absorption. Option C: Gastric secretions increase iron absorption by dissolving the iron and allowing it to form soluble complexes with ascorbic and other substances. This helps in its reduction to the Fe2+ form. Antacid decreases the absorption of iron. Option D: Tannins (present in tea), phytates, phosphates, and oxalates form insoluble complexes with iron and lower its absorption.
subject: Physiology

question_text: All of the following regulates intestinal absorption of iron except:
options: State of iron stores in the body
State of erythropoiesis in bone marrow
explanation: Intestinal absorption of iron is not regulated by the daily loss of iron. The intestinal absorption of iron is regulated by three factors: Recent dietary intake of iron State of the iron stores in the body State of erythropoiesis in the bone marrow
subject: Physiology

question_text: What is the end product after the action of colonic bacteria on dietary fiber?
explanation: The action of colonic bacteria on dietary fiber would give butyrate. Colonic bacteria act on complex carbohydrates, resistant starches, and dietary fiber to form short-chain fatty acids such as acetate, propionate, and butyrate. SCFAs are 2–5-carbon weak acids that have an average normal concentration of about 80 mmol/L in the lumen.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Where are the cell bodies of the orexinergic neurons are present in a patient?
explanation: Cell bodies of orexigenic neurons are present in the lateral hypothalamic area. Orexin stimulates food intake. Role of hypothalamus in gastrointestinal and feeding regulation: Hunger center - lateral hypothalamic area Satiety center - ventromedial nuclei Feeding reflexes such as licking the lips and swallowing - mammillary bodies. Note: The arcuate nucleus contains at least two different types of neurons that when stimulated lead to either increased or decreased appetite.
subject: Physiology

question_text: In a patient who is fasting, the stomach releases a hormone that increases food intake. Identify the hormone secreted.
explanation: The hormone secreted by the stomach that increases food intake is ghrelin. Ghrelin, the hunger hormone is produced by the endocrine cells in the oxyntic glands of the stomach. It increases food intake. Its levels increase during fasting, peaks just before the beginning of food intake, or when the person is expecting a meal. The levels fall within 1 hour of the start of feeding. Option A: Orexin is synthesized from lateral hypothalamic neurons. It increases food intake. Option B: Leptin is produced by adipocytes. It decreases food intake. Option C: CCK is released from the small intestine. It decreases food intake.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding ghrelin?
explanation: Ghrelin increases gastric acid secretion. Ghrelin is mainly produced by the endocrine cells in the oxyntic gland area of the stomach. It is also secreted by the pancreas and adrenal glands. Functions: Increases appetite/food intake (orexigenic) Inhibits leptin release Stimulates growth hormone secretion by directly acting on anterior pituitary (ghrelin-growth hormone-releasing peptide) Increases gastric acid secretion and gastrointestinal motility to prepare the body for food intake Regulates the distribution and rate of use of energy
subject: Physiology

question_text: What will be the trend of leptin levels in a patient with a BMI of 34 kg/m2.
explanation: A patient with a BMI of 34 kg/m2 is categorized as obese. Leptin levels are high in obesity. Leptin is an appetite-suppressing hormone synthesized from adipocytes. The larger the fat stores, the more leptin is released into the blood. Leptin resistance in obese persons may be due to its failure to cross the blood-brain barrier and reach the hypothalamus to serve its appetite-suppressing function. Note: A recent study has indicated that triglycerides which are elevated in obesity, inhibit the transport of leptin across the blood-brain barrier.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber?
explanation: Gum is the best answer among the given options. Even though all of the given options are dietary fibers, the consumption of gums through diet is very low and hence, it is the best answer. Dietary fibers consist of both soluble and insoluble forms and include lignin, pectin, inulin, cellulose, hemicellulose, etc. Advantages of fibers: Forms bulk of the stool and reduces stool transit time Reduces incidence of carcinoma colon, DM, CAD, diverticuliti
subject: Physiology

question_text: All of the following have a significant role in lipid digestion except:
explanation: Lingual lipases are of little quantitative significance for lipid digestion other than in the setting of pancreatic insufficiency. Lingual lipase is secreted by Ebner glands on the dorsal surface of the tongue in some species, and the stomach also secretes lipase. Digestion of Lipids Pancreatic lipase is the most important enzyme involved in lipid digestion. The main products of its action are FFA and 2-monoglycerides (2-monoacylglycerols) Colipase is an accessory factor secreted in the pancreatic juice that helps to stabilize pancreatic lipase in an active conformation Bile acids emulsify the insoluble lipids and make them reach the surface of the mucosal cells. Bile acids also activate another pancreatic lipase called cholesterol esterase Cholesterol esterase hydrolyzes cholesterol esters, esters of fat-soluble vitamins, phospholipids, and triglyceride
subject: Physiology

question_text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
explanation: After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. Vitamin B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Transport molecule for Fe2+ into the enterocytes is
explanation: Transport of Fe2+ into the enterocytes occurs via divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1), through an active transport process. Protein DMT-1 (Divalent Metal Transporter-1) is expressed on the apical surface of enterocytes in the initial part of the duodenum. DMT-1 is not specific to iron & transports other substances like zinc, copper, cobalt & manganese.
subject: Physiology

question_text:
Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?
Ito cell
explanation: Vitamin A is stored in the liver perisinusoidal stellate (Ito) cells as retinyl ester (retinol palmitate). Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specialized macrophages located in the liver that form part of the mononuclear phagocyte system. These are present, lining the walls of the sinusoids, not the perisinusoidal space (Space of Disse). GI Peristalsis and Motility
subject: Physiology

question_text: Slow waves are generated by:
explanation: The interstitial cells of Cajal undergo cyclic changes in membrane potential due to unique ion channels that periodically open and produce inward (pacemaker) currents that generate slow-wave activity. Interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells of the GIT that initiate the basic electrical rhythm (BER). These are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features. In the stomach and the small intestine, these cells are located in the circular smooth muscle layer near the myenteric plexus. In the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer. The slow waves usually do not by themselves cause muscle contraction in most parts of the gastrointestinal tract, except perhaps in the stomach. Instead, they mainly excite the appearance of intermittent spike potentials, and the spike potentials in turn actually excite the muscle contraction. Note: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Least frequency of slow waves is seen in:
explanation: Among the given options, the least frequency of slow waves is seen in the stomach (4/min). The Basal electrical rhythm (BER) also called slow-wave, is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. It is initiated by the interstitial cells of Cajal. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65mV and -45mV. The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach. The rate of BER in various sites is as follows: Stomach: 4/min Duodenum: 12/min Distal ileum: 8/min Cecum: 2/min Sigmoid colon: 6/min The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension. Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension. Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension. Muscle contraction can occur only when the motor stimulus is provided during the depolarisation part of the BER. Thus, BER does not cause muscle contraction by itself, but controls the rate and organization sites of the muscle contractions, as in coordination of the peristaltic activity and setting the rhythm of segmentation.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Slow waves are maximum in which part of the intestine?
explanation: Among the given options, the frequency of 'slow waves' is maximum in the ileum (8/min). Normal intestinal motility is determined by two patterns of electrical activity - slow waves and spike potentials. Slow waves, also known as basic electrical rhythm are partial depolarizations of smooth muscle cells, spreading along the GIT. They originate from the interstitial cells of Cajal. The smooth muscles are in a hyperpolarized state, having a resting membrane potential of -50 to -60mV. These waves are not action potentials themselves and they do not cause any contractions. Slow waves raise the membrane potential by 5-15mV, bringing it closer to the threshold enabling spike potential (true action potential) to occur. Therefore, they set the basic rhythm of GIT.
subject: Physiology

question_text: As a part of cranial nerves examination, swallowing reflex is performed on a patient. Which of the following is not involved in afferent limb of this reflex?
explanation: The facial nerve is a part of an efferent limb (and not afferent) of the swallowing reflex. Swallowing/ deglutition refle x Afferents Trigeminal nerveGlossophary ngeal nerveVagus nerve Centre Nucleus of the tractus solitari usNucleus ambig-uus Efferents Trigeminal nerveFacial nerve Hypoglossal nerve
subject: Physiology

question_text: Chyme is propelled forward in small intestine by
explanation: Chyme is propelled forward in the intestine by the peristaltic movement. Chyme is a thick semifluid mass of partially digested food and digestive secretions that is expelled by the stomach into the duodenum. Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front. Segmentation consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward. It is the small intestine’s primary method of motility during digestion of a meal. Migrating motor complexes (MMC) are the peristaltic motor patterns that occur during fasting. They migrate from the stomach to the distal ileum. Haustrations are the characteristic saclike segments seen in the large intestine.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is the major initiating response for peristalsis?
explanation: The major initiating response for peristalsis is local stretching of the gut. Peristalsis is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. It occurs in all parts of the gastrointestinal tract from the esophagus to the rectum. The stretch initiates a circular contraction behind the stimulus and an area of relaxation in front of it. The wave of contraction then moves in an oral-to-caudal direction. This propels the contents of the lumen forward at rates that vary from 2 to 25 cm/s.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is seen in a patient on parasympathetic stimulation?
explanation: Parasympathetic stimulation results in increased peristalsis. Generally, the stimulation of parasympathetic nerves (PNS) causes an increase in the activity of the entire enteric nervous system. This, in turn, enhances the activity of most gastrointestinal functions. PNS stimulation causes: Contraction of smooth muscle in the wall Relaxation of sphincters  Salivary secretion  Gastric secretion  Pancreatic secretion SNS stimulation causes: Relaxation of smooth muscle in the wall Contraction of sphincters
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?
explanation: VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine. Peristalsis involves the contraction of a segment of intestine behind the bolus of food and relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus of food. Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus. Note: In achalasia cardia, there is decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of the esophagus.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following neurotransmitters acts on the muscle, behind a bolus of food, in the process of peristalsis?
explanation: Substance P and acetylcholine are released from neurons behind the bolus of food, causing smooth muscle contraction, which propels the food downwards. NO and VIP are released by neurons in the anterograde direction from the bolus which produces relaxation in front of the stimulus.
subject: Physiology

question_text: All of the following stimulates gastric motility except:
explanation: Encephalin inhibits the motility of the stomach. ECL: enterochromaffin-like Function Source Stimulate secretion Function Source Function Source Gastrin G-cells Histamine ECL cells Acetylcholine Neurones Gastrin-releasing peptide Neurones and mucosa Cholecystokinin (CCK) Duodenal endocrine cells Inhibit secretion Somatostatin D-cells and neurones Secretin Duodenal endocrine cells Enteroglucagon Small intestinal endocrine cel ls Prostaglandins Mucosa Neurotensin Neurones GIP Duodenal and jejunal endocri ne cells PYY Small intestinal endocrine cel ls Stimulate motility Acetylcholine Neurones 5-HT Neurones Histamine ECL cells Substance P Neurones Substance K Neurones Motilin Neurones Gastrin G-cells Angiotensin Inhibit motility Somatostatin D-cells and neurones VIP Neurones Nitric oxide Neurones and smooth muscl e Noradrenaline Neurones Encephalin Neurones Dopamine Neurones
subject: Physiology

question_text: Gastric emptying is mainly regulated by which of the following mechanisms?
explanation: Gastric emptying is mainly regulated by enteric reflexes. Regulation of gastric emptying is mainly by the inhibitory feedback signals from the duodenum that includes enterogastric reflex and hormonal feedback by cholecystokinin. Enterogastric reflex: When food enters the duodenum, multiple nervous reflexes are initiated from the duodenal wall. They strongly inhibit the pyloric pump propulsive contractions and increase the tone of the pyloric sphincter. These reflexes are mediated by three routes: Directly from the duodenum to the stomach through the enteric nervous system in the gut wall (major role) Through inhibitory sympathetic nerve fibers to the stomach (minor role) Vagus nerves to the brain stem where they inhibit the normal excitatory signals transmitted to the stomach (minor role) Hormonal feedback: Cholecystokinin is released from the mucosa of the jejunum in response to fatty substances in the chyme. This hormone acts as an inhibitor to block increased stomach motility caused by gastrin.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which among the following increases gastric emptying?
explanation: The distension of the stomach increases gastric emptying. Distension activates the mechanoreceptors that trigger long and short reflexes in the stomach. This increases the force of antral contraction and gastric emptying.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following does not delay gastric emptying?
explanation: Gastrin increases gastric emptying. It does not delay it. Gastrin has mild to moderate stimulatory effects on motor functions in the body of the stomach. Thus, gastrin likely promotes stomach emptying.
subject: Physiology

question_text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?
explanation: In the enterogastric reflex, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum. When the food enters the duodenum, multiple reflexes are initiated from the duodenal wall which passes back to the stomach. These reflexes slow or stop the stomach emptying if the volume of the chyme in the duodenum becomes too much. These reflexes are called enterogastric reflexes. This reflex can be triggered due to the following reasons: Presence of irritants and acids in duodenal chyme (most sensitive factor) Distension of duodenum due to the presence of an excessive volume of chyme Rapid entry of hypertonic or hypotonic fluids into the duodenum Presence of breakdown products of protein digestion and sometimes fat
subject: Physiology

question_text: Enterogastric inhibitory reflexes are stimulated by all of the following except:
explanation: Enterogastric inhibitory reflexes are stimulated by acidic contents, not alkaline. The duodenal factors that can initiate enterogastric inhibitory reflexes (enterogastric reflexes) are: Distention of the duodenum Presence of any irritation of the duodenal mucosa Acidity of the duodenal chyme Osmolality of the chyme - either hypotonic or hypertonic fluid initiate enterogastric inhibitory eflexes. Thus, the flow of non-isotonic fluids into the small intestine is regulated. This prevents apid changes in electrolyte concentrations in the extracellular fluid during the absorption of the intestinal contents. Presence of certain breakdown products in the chyme, especially proteins and to a lesser extent, of fats
subject: Physiology

question_text: A concerned mother brings her infant to the OPD for advice regarding nutrition. She says, soon after every meal, her kid defecates. What is the cause of colonic contraction in this situation?
explanation: The cause of colonic contraction in the given situation is due to gastrocolic reflex. Distension of the stomach by food initiates contractions of the rectum and frequently, a desire to defecate. This response is called the gastrocolic reflex. Because of this response, defecation after meals is common in children. This response may be amplified by the action of gastrin on the colon.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The following image shows which type of GI motility?
explanation: The given image shows the migrating motor complex. The image shows 3 phases: Phase I - quiescent period Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity This occurs during the inter-digestive period at intervals of about 100 min and passes in the aboral direction at the rate of 5 cm/min. Its main function is to clear intestinal contents and prepare for the next meal. Option A: Peristalsis is a propulsive movement, which consists of a segment of contraction behind and relaxation in front. Option B: Segmentation and mixing help in mixing intestinal contents with digestive juices and provides time for digestion and absorption. It consists of a segment of bowel contracting at both ends, and then a second contraction occurs in the center of the segment to force the chyme both backward and forward. Option D: Basal Electrical Rhythm is fluctuation in the resting membrane potential of smooth muscle cells of the intestine as shown below.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Migrating motor complexes occurs at the rate of and at an interval of
explanation: Migrating motor complex (MMC) migrates from the stomach to the distal ileum at a rate of about 5 cm/min and also occurs at intervals of approximately 100 minutes. MMC is a type of gastrointestinal motility that occurs during fasting between periods of digestion. It is initiated by motilin. It helps to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal. Gastric secretion, bile flow, and pancreatic secretion increase during each MMC. After ingestion of a meal, secretion of motilin is suppressed and the MMC is abolished. Each cycle of MMC has 3 phases Phase I - quiescent period Phase II - period of irregular electrical & mechanical activity Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity Note: Disorders of MMC have been associated with gastroparesis, intestinal pseudo-obstruction, and small intestinal bacterial overgrowth.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following is true about gastroduodenal motor activity?
options: Migrating motor complex/MMC in the fasting state lasts for 50 minutes
Duodenal slow waves are limited to the duodenum
From the duodenum, the MMC moves distally at 5-10 cm/min
The amplitude of contraction decreases to a minimum in phase III of MMC
explanation: From the duodenum, the migrating motor complex (MMC) moves distally at 5–10 cm/min, reaching the terminal ileum after 1.5 hours. In the fasting state, there is a period of quiescence in the small bowel, lasting for approximately 40 minutes (phase I). This is followed by a series of waves, also lasting for about 40 minutes, propagating from the fundus of the stomach in a caudal direction at a rate of about 3 per minute (phase II). Duodenal slow waves are generated in the duodenum at a rate of about 10 per minute, which carry down the small bowel. The amplitude of these contractions increases to a maximum in phase III, which lasts for about 10 minutes. This 90-minute cycle of activity is then repeated.
subject: Physiology

question_text: Which of the following does not increase small intestinal motility?
explanation: Secretin inhibits small intestinal motility. Factors that increase the peristaltic activity of the small intestine: Hormonal - gastrin, CCK, insulin, motilin, and serotonin. Neural - duodenal distension by chyme, gastroenteric reflexes, gastroileal reflexes, parasympathetic (Ach) stimulation. Factors that decrease the peristaltic activity of the small intestine: Hormonal - secretin and glucagon. Neural - sympathetic stimulation. Gastroileal reflex - On reaching the ileocecal valve, the chyme is sometimes blocked for several hours until the person eats another meal. question_text: Which of the following formulae is correct?
explanation: True renal plasma flow (RPF) is obtained by dividing effective renal plasma flow (ERPF) by extraction ratio. Using that, to we calculate the true RPF, we divide it by the extraction ratio to account for the 10% that is not filtered by dividing the ERPF by 0.9, hence getting the final value of ~ 700mL per minute When peripheral venous plasma concentration of PAH is used for calculation of RPF, RPF obtained is called effective renal plasma flow (ERPF). question_text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by
explanation: The afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch induced by the opening of calcium channels. The mechanism is called myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow and GFR. The stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction prevents excessive stretch of the vessel. This prevents excessive increase of renal blood flow and GFR by raising vascular resistance. This mechanism may be more important in protecting the kidney from hypertension-induced injury. Renal autoregulation is present in denervated and in isolated, perfused kidneys. Efferent arteriolar constriction has a biphasic response on GFR depending on the severity of resistance. However, in cases of severe efferent arteriolar constriction (more than threefold increase in efferent arteriolar resistance), the renal blood flow is significantly reduced. This results in increased plasma protein concentration, thereby increasing the glomerular colloid oncotic pressure. As the increase in colloid oncotic pressure exceeds the increase in hydrostatic pressure, the net force for filtration decreases, resulting in decreased GFR.

explanation: In the given graph, the order of filterability is A>B>C, which likely indicates that the substances are Polycationic, Neutral, Polyanionic. The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged, which will repel most of the negative charged (anionic substances). Whereas, the cationic substances are easily filtered. Hence, the order of filterability would be: Polycationic > Neutral > Polyanionic, represented by A, B, and C in the graph shown. The glomerular filtration barrier consists of: Endothelium of the capillary Basement membrane: Lamina densa - electron-dense layer. It contains type IV collagen Lamina rara interna - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charg Lamina rara externa - contains glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charg Layer of epithelial cells (podocytes) surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement membran The capillary endothelium is perforated by thousands of small holes called fenestrae, which measure from 4 nm up to 8nm. Therefore, neutral substances with molecular diameters of less than 4 nm are freely filtered, and filtration of those with diameters of more than 8 nm approaches zero. However, in addition to the size of the particles, the filtration also depends mainly on the charge of the particle being filtered. The glomerular capillary wall consists of highly negatively charged proteins called sialoproteins, which repel the negatively charged substances (anions). The property can be studied by using charged dextran. When the filtration of the negatively and positively charged dextrans was studied, the results indicated that the negatively charged dextrans in the blood are repelled, with the result that filtration of anionic substances 4 nm in diameter is less than half that of neutral substances of the same size. This explains, why albumin despite having an effective molecular diameter of approximately 7 nm, has a very low filtration rate. Renal Tubular Functions, Urine Concentration and Dilution

Normal renal threshold (g/L) and transport maxima (mg/min) for glucose respectively are
,
explanation: The actual renal threshold is about 200 mg/dL (i.e., 2 g/L ) (1g/L=100mg/dl) and the transport maximum for glucose is 375 mg/min. For substances that are actively reabsorbed or secreted, there is a limit to the rate at which the solute can be transported, which is referred to as the transport maximum. This limit is due to saturation of the specific transport systems involved. Normally, measurable glucose does not appear in the urine because essentially all the filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. The transport maximum for glucose is about 375 mg/min, whereas the filtered load of glucose is only about 125 mg/min. With large increases in GFR and/or plasma glucose concentration that increase the filtered load of glucose above 375 mg/min, the excess glucose filtered is not reabsorbed and passes into the urine. When the plasma glucose concentration is 100 mg/100 ml and the filtered load is at its normal level (125 mg/min) there is no loss of glucose in the urine. However, when the plasma concentration of glucose rises above about 200 mg/100 ml, increasing the filtered load to about 250 mg/min, a small amount of glucose begins to appear in the urine. This point is termed as the threshold for glucose. Splay is due to separation between filtered load and exceretion. It occurs due to different transport maximums of different nephrons.
subject: Physiology

question_text: The image of PAH excretion is depicted below. Match the labellings.
options: Filtered, b. Excreted, c. Tm, d. Secreted
Filtered, b. Secreted, c. Tm, d. Excreted
Secreted, b. Filtered, c. Tm, d. Excreted
Excreted, b. Filtered, c. Tm, d. Secreted
explanation: The labellings depticed are a. Filtered, b. Secreted, c. Tm, d. Excreted Filtered Load: The filtered load of PAH increases linearly as the unbound concentration of PAH increases (filtered load = GFR. [P]PAH). Secretion: At low concentrations of PAH, many carriers are available and secretion increases linearly as the plasma concentration increases. When the PAH concentration increases to a level where the carriers are saturated, Tm is reached. After this point, no matter how much the PAH concentration increases, there can be no further increase in the secretion rate. Excretion. For a secreted substance such as PAH, excretion is the sum of filtration and secretion. At low PAH concentrations (below Tm), excretion increases steeply with increases in plasma PAH concentration because both filtration and secretion are increasing. At PAH concentrations above Tm, excretion increases less steeply (and parallels the curve for filtration) because only the filtration component increases as concentration increases; secretion is already saturated.

question_text: In a patient with uncontrolled diabetes, what is the value of plasma clearance of glucose?
explanation: In uncontrolled diabetes, the plasma clearance of glucose is greater than zero. Normally, all the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed and no glucose is excreted in the urine. Hence, the clearance is zero. In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorption, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero. Clearance of different substances can be shown in a graph as follows: The above graph depicts renal handling of glucose, inulin, and para-aminohippurate (PAH) and can be explained as follows: Glucose clearance: Normally, all the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed and no glucose is excreted in the urine. Hence, the clearance is zero. In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorption, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero. Inulin clearance: Inulin is freely filtered and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted. Hence, it is constant and equal to the glomerular filtration rate. PAH clearance: PAH is both filtered and secreted. When plasma PAH is low, clearance is high. However, as plasma PAH rises above the threshold level for PAH secretion, clearance falls progressively.

question_text: A patient has a ■blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below?
explanation: The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min. Calculation: Step 1: Calculate total filtered glucose: In this question, GFR = 90 ml/min Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml). Total filtered glucose = GFR X Plasma glucose concentration. = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml = 180 mg/min. Step 2: Check transport maximum: In the above question transport maximum is 150 mg/min. Step 3: Calculate the excretion: Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum) = 180-150 mg/min = 30 mg/min

question_text: A dehydrated patient is excreting hypertonic urine. Absorption of water in which part of the nephron causes this?

The basic requirements for forming a concentrated urine (hypertonic urine) are A high level of ADH, which increases the permeability of the distal tubules and collecting ducts to water, thereby allowing these tubular segments to avidly reabsorb water. A high osmolarity of the renal medullary interstitial fluid, which provides the osmotic gradient necessary for water reabsorption to occur in the presence of high levels of ADH.

question_text:
Macula densa is formed by which part of the nephron?
PCT
explanation: Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule. The juxtaglomerular apparatus consists of the following parts: Macula densa: At the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle, and at the beginning of the dista tubule, the tubular epithelial cells are specialized to form the macula densa. They detect sodium concentration of the fluid in the tubule (chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR. Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure. Acid-Base Balance, Renal Hormones and Micturition Reflex

question_text: Normal anion gap is mostly due to

Diagnostically, when the electrolytes are measured in the blood, routinely only certain cations and anions are measured. These are Na+, Cl- and HCO3-. The anion gap is the difference between the unmeasured anions and unmeasured cations. This is estimated as : Plasma anion gap= [Na+] - [Cl-] - [HCO3-] The unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium and potassium. The unmeasured anions include albumin, phosphate, sulphate and organic anions. This is primarily used in measurement of different causes of metabolic acidosis.

The cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl and HCO3. The “anion gap” (which is only a diagnostic concept) is the difference between unmeasured anions and unmeasured cations and is estimated as Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ]  [HCO3 ]  [Cl ]=14424108 =12 mEq/L The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall. question_text: Ureteric peristalsis is mainly due to

The walls of the ureters contain smooth muscle and are innervated by both sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves, as well as by an intramural plexus of neurons and nerve fibers that extends along the entire length of the ureters.
